text: Bottle. BB 30.08.2017. Dark brown; big tan head. Molasses sweet and black rye bread bitter, some spiciness (cardamom?), moderate roastiness, fruity esters, considerable licorice aftertaste. Very soft, albeit a bit flat, on the palate. Dry, roasty finish. Nice!
From bottle. Pours black with medium, brown head. Dark bread, roasted malts, coffee, alcohol note, chocolate sweets. Medium to high carbonation, medium body, long, roasty aftertaste.

Very dark brown, motor oil in color with a short lived mahogany colored head. Toast and molasses with baking cocoa scented. Strong roasted malts, shoyu, dark coffee that was left in the pot too long, leather, mineral salt, black pepper. Nice feel. Mild spritz, bitter follow with burnt toast flavors. Decent.
12oz can pours black with medium tan head aroma was pretty flat slight roast taste was well balanced between coffee, molasses and licorice enjoyed it

Small can from High Point Liquor in Vancouver. A black beer with moderate tan head and sweet nose of roasted malts. Rich, sweet, creamy, flavorful dark roasted malts abound. Sort of like a lighter impy stout, Id say. 3.7

This beer makes a good argument that a solid stout doesnt need barrel aging, coffee beans, or other ancillary affectations to stand out. It pours black as hell with an average head that fades quickly. The aroma is anise, strong herbal notes, some lemon and molasses. The flavor is really big, very dark roasted malts and some coriander atop everything in the aroma. Im still gonna seek out my barrel aged favorites, but stouts like Fade To Black Volume One are a great reminder that there are wonderful beers that never touch oak.

12floz can (BBD: 11.29.2017, $2) poured into a nonic glass. Its dark (for practical purposes black) with a slight light brown head. Aroma is alright in a generic basic dark roasted grain sense. The palate is slick, moderately roasty with a kick of alcohol felt in the finish. This is pretty blahzay, its just another typical strong stout that is classified as a foreign stout - in this category Ive had a better and some about the same in quality.
Almost black with medium brown head. Sweet aroma with umami notes. Medium bitterness with some sourness and roasted malt and umami notes

The beer sends forth a malty roast smell immediately upon popping the cap. It pours black with a very thin head, still putting out that alcohol smell.
Like many "export" beers, this runs stronger than the regular version, maybe at 8.5% it could be considered an Imperial stout. The alcohol warmth helps ease out the usual roastiness of a stout, letting slip in later in the glass. Without the smoothness left by bourbon barrel aging, this beer has to stand out on its own. And the roast and alcohol do a good job of that.

This seems like it fits in well as a foreign stout, a bit of extra complexity and body perhaps over stout. Lots of licorice in the nose along with candy sweetness, a bit of campfire and oreos. Very dark pour, tan head, sparse with spotty lacing. Thick syrupy mouthfeel, lots of charred notes, oily, sweet, alcohol hidden. Quite good.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2017 Almost black in colour with a small tan head that quickly disappeared. Aroma is coffee, chocolate and licorice. Moderately sweet taste, coffee, chocolate and roasted flavours. Smooth given high alcohol content, a long finish.

Black beer with little white head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, licorice. Taste is mild sweet chocolate, after comes little bitter and strong licorice and some hints of smoke. Nice creamy texture. Medium body. Good enjoyable stout and still easy drinkable.
Can. Black with no head. Liquorice and a slight spiciness are the main flavours. Smooth and slightly bitter. Impressive.
How: bottle Appearance: almost black, medium to small tanned head. Aroma: coffee, chocholate, toast, nuts and caramel. Palate: medium body, soft carbonation.

Near black tan head nose is milk chocolate taste chocolate lactose on a blind tasting would have said this was a sweet stout smooth and velvety. Some light smoke comes through later through the drink.
Near black. Rich and toasty, deep malts, light smoke and licorice. Great body. Very nice example of the style

Can from High Point, Vancouver, best by 11/29/17Dark brown color, near black, with small head. Some milk cream, light smoke, chocolate. Semi-sweet, chocolate flavor, and some roastiness in the final; the high ABV is well hidden.A bit boring, but not bad.

355ml can @ Matts. Pours an oily opaque black with no head. Nose eludes me. Flavour is also weak and/or bland. The only redeeming quality is the smoothness of how well the abv is integreated. Nothing special here.

Dark brown. Fudgey chocolatey aroma. A bit thin on the body. Doesnt have the sugars or esters that one would expect in a foreign stout...just an American stout. Some subtle smoke and toffee so its okay that way. Just not foreign stout at all, but when did Americans ever understand that style?

12 oz. can, pours black with a tiny beige head. Aroma brings out lots of licorice and chicory upfront, followed by earthy toasted malt and a little cardamom. Flavour is similar, with lots of earthy malt, chicory and cardamom. Very odd flavours, but somehow it works reasonably well. Not a big fan of the flavours, but I can appreciate its uniqueness. Decent.

Can from Wine Rack, West Byfleet. Liquorice, coffee and spice aroma - the blurb on that can aint wrong. Dark, with hints of ruby red when held up in the light. Frothy head soon dissipates - interesting colours: an orange/red tinted beige with some paler areas. Coffee is in the forefront of the taster. The liquorice then comes through and it gains in spices trough into the aftertaste. A creaminess smooths away the spicier elements. Medium bodied. Creamy but also leaves a slick sensation on the back of the teeth. Prickly carbonation. Long finish - astringent with a boozy hit. Enjoyable - smooth and creamy but also lively and packing some punch..
Pitch black, foamy beige head. Light, toasted malt aroma.Flavour is rich and malty, with a hefty hit of chocolate, liquorice, coffee. Creamy mouthfeel. Absolutely delicious.

Coco bean, vanilla, woody smell the taste is smokey bitter chocolate, black licorice, the look is solid black. Great taste, wish there was a little more sweetness but this is a solid beer. Perfect ABV at 8.5.

I really enjoyed this, it achieved a great balance and drinkability, avoiding the pitfalls of the big stout genre. Nice roast, coffee and dark chocolate notes, nice full sweetness.Good full palate but not overwhelming or coating - softer mouthfeel despite the fullness. Somewhat creamy texture (but not in the horrible nitro way).
Kivääritehtaankadulla 1/2017. Very enjoyable black ipa, balanced and smooth. Recommendable.
ratings are always a bit off after sauna. Nice aroma and taste of coffee/espresso and roasted notes. A lot of the good bits from imperial stouts, but with out going over 9%. well done.

The ingredients say this is wheat beer: water, malted barely, malted wheat, hops, & yeast. But they must have smoked it, because it goes down like a good German rauchbier, while being darker than any rauchbier I've ever had. The bouquet has notes of licorice, and it is dark as night. The taste is smoked stout, and what could possibly be better. Simply put, this is the best smoked beer I've ever had. It is also a fantastic stout, and an incredible beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can. Black with a big foamy tan head that has rather good retention. The aroma is big and bold with old leather, anise, a bit of spice and some cocoa. The taste, like the aroma, features leather and cocoa with bitter black walnuts filling in the back end. The palate is medium and this finishes rather sticky. Overall: Top shelf stout.

Flaska från SB. Kolsvart, opak. lite trög vätska med ganska lågt mörkbeige skum. Doft med massor av choklad, värmande alkohol, lite kaffe, mörk torkad frukt. Stor kropp, stora smaker, mycket choklad, en aningen rökighet och aska. Stor och maffig, bra balans och hyfsat lättdrucken. Gott

Medium, slightly pungent aroma with espresso, vanilla and some of that cardamom. Pitch black color with minimal, light beige head. Medium/strong, balanced taste with slightly bitter licorice, espresso, some roasted malts and spices (mostly cardamon). A hint of lactose? Medium taste spectrum and medium aftertaste with roasted malts. Medium body with medium/light carbonation. Overall, nice quality and somewhat distinctive though not too special.

Can. Black with an average tan head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is rich with dark roasted malts, cocoa, anise, and cream. Taste is full of coffee, chocolate, cocoa, licorice, and vanilla cream. Thicker and lingering creamy flavors with licorice.
Bottle, 13/01/17. Pours dark brown, black with a small, dark latte-colored head. Aroma is smoke, roast, liquorice. Taste is roast, smoke, liquorice, dark fruit. Pleasant.

Ar: Complex aroma of leather, vinous, cocoa, and licorice; herbal hop note; currant, burnt caramel, treacle, and rum. Ap: Pitch black with a medium mocha-colored head; moderate-low retention, leaves a thin trail on the side of glass and a filmy head with blotches of foam and a loose ring. T: Dark fruit and vinous up front; cocoa and char, slightly milky, plus notes of licorice and deeply burnt caramel; medium and firm bitterness, hop flavor is herbal and dark berries; medium sweetness throughout, finish is medium and slightly ashy. P: Medium-full body with medium-high carbonation, creamy and silky with a medium-dry finish. O: Absolutely excellent foreign stout; bold malt character, with lots of ash, burnt caramel, and dark fruit character, without any single aspect overwhelming the other or being too over-the-top; at once, hoppy, rich, roasty, and filled with tons of harmonious malt flavors.

Thic motor oil pours black and gives a brown creamy head, good lacing. Sweet and roasted, salty licorice, soy sauce, coffee, alcohol, mildly ash. Medium to full body, dry, roasted, lots coffee here to long finish, standard carbonation. Ok, tasty. Latte chocolate went very nicely with this.

Can pour into tulip glass from Greg & Janes Beer and Wine. Appearance is opaque black with finger-width light brown foamy head with poor retention and trace lacing. Aroma is light roasted malts with earthy European hops, mild vanilla and chocolate. Taste is moderately strong roasted malts with hint of smoke/ash, molasses, cardamom, vanilla and light chocolate and licorice. Palate is full bodied with thick texture, lively carbonation and long balanced sweet and bitter finish.
Overall, nice complexity and delicious.
Bottle. Black color, brown head. Nice aroma has some spices, coffee, some roasted malts. Balanced roasty body, spices, some vanilla notes.
355ml bottle from Alko Viikki. This rather adventurous brew reminds me of saying: One person with passion is better than forty people merely interested." -E. M. Forster

Bottle. Dark color. Thin beige head. Body is medium. Dry body. Long dry finish. Medium sweetness, medium bitterness. Aroma and flavour is malt, chocolate, liquorice, pepper, spices, hops, roasted, chocolate, vanilla.

Bottle at home from Drinkstore 
Opaque ruby tinged brown with tan lacing. Very unusual stewed dates and vegetal solvent aroma. Gentle carbonation, full bodied, rich, cocoa, slightly minty, toasty dry finish. Tasty stuff but maybe I left it too long to try.

Best by stamp on the bottom of the can 11/14/2017.
This was poured into a mini-snifter.
The appearance was a jet black pour and left the same color body. Moderate lacing appears after the head dissipates quickly. But even that lacing just slides right on into the beer.
The aroma exacts a nice super rich compounded roasty coffee bean up front. A moderate sweet espresso bean comes in and then some subtle vanilla bean. Light molasses is far underneath.
The flavor bends all of the previously mentioned aromas into each other for a mighty fine blend, sweet and roasty with a touch of blended in spice (must be the cardamom). Mainly a roasty aftertaste with a quick roasty finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium in body with an ability to show some session, is the ABV too well hidden? Can says its supposed to sit at 8.5%, but the way this feels, Id say yes, I feel like I could crush it.
Overall, Id say the aroma and flavor was the best thing about this beer and very well done in those departments, but the feel, to me at least, I think with the canning date, I was expecting a little more "beef to the body." Other than that, Id still have again. Lets just call it a "session foreign/export stout."

(Bottle, 0.355 l - bottled on 30/08/2016 - BB 30/08/2017, from Alko, 20161223) The beer poured black. Its head was medium sized and lightly brown. Aroma had coffee, burnt malts and ash. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were dark chocolate, spiciness, sweetness, burnt malts, coffee and bitterness. Aftertaste had dark chocolate, ash and bitterness. A tasty burnt brew.

There is no light coming through; blackness! Quick tan head. Nose is coco and cherries, espresso. Bittersweet. Middle shows a little wood, currants, treacle, smoky blackened malt. Finish is surprisingly restrained bittersweet malt. Powerful beer.

Inky black pour under a thin sticky light tan head. Earthy smokey/roasty blackmalt on the aroma and some bittersweet cocoa. Really bold flavor with rich smokey chocolate, earthy roasted semisweet black malts and a smooth boozy background that amplifies the earthy toasted chocolate tones. Really delightful.

Poured from the bottle into a tulip glass to drink. The beer had a somewhat watery consistency with a dark black color below a very small, foamy dark tan head with short retention, and modest cling and lacing. Its aroma featured bread, grain, and cereal hop tones along with some lighter fruit and floral tones mixed with caramel. The taste was forwardly sweet with a blend of subtle fruit flavors, caramel malt, and some bread, but quickly yielded to a more bitter grainy and earthy taste for a good finish. The beer was quite smooth and crisp with average carbonation, a pleasant wet mouthfeel, and a smooth finish. Excellent beer, which probably would have gotten even better had I been able to wait longer for it to warm up a touch.
Aika mieto. Voisi olla paljonkin enemmän makua. Toisaalta ei maistunut viinaakaan. Ok, ei mahtava.

12 oz bottle. Bottled on 30/08/2016. (Alko) Espoo, Finland.
Black color with a small tan head. 
Licorice, roasted malt, oil and mild sewer in the aroma. 
Roasted malt, darkness, licorice, charcoal and dryness in the flavor. 
Really good... but you just wait for a twist... theres none.
Bottle. Pours black with small light brown head. Aroma has roasted malt, ashes and coffee. Taste has burnt malt + ashes, roasted malt and some coffee.

Black body, creamy, tan lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, some spices. Bitter taste, slightly roasted malts, bitter roasty finish. Silky smooth mouthfeel, medium body and carbonation. Very nice.
Pours black with light beige head. Aroma is smoky, roasted and coffee. Flavour is roasted, smoke, light to medium bitter and notes of charcoal.

A black beer, a head is medium and brown. Aroma has coffee, caramel malts, some liquirice, hint of meat. Taste has strong maltyness, caramel, some roastiness of coffee and smoke. Medium+ bodied, quite smooth. Slightly unique and also complex. Good beer.

Really dark brown color with tan head. Aroma has nice fudge, milk chocolate and some fresh coffee. Taste starts with fudge, continues with bitter chocolate and finishes with roasted coffee. Medium body, carbonation is on the low side. Overall its quite good, classic and tasty.

355ml bottle from Alko, kokkola. Pours black with a thick, big off-white head. Aroma is mostly oat, roasted malt and chocolate. Smooth, warm mouthfeel. Flavor is licqorice, coffee, chocolate some roastedness. Nicely hidden ABV.

Dark brown colour with beige smallish head on top. Aroma has burnt notes, roasted malts, espresso coffee, some sweetness. Taste has roasted malts, burnt even and slight smoke with espresso coffee. Almost full body with medium carbonation, feels a bit light though. Id wanted more bolder flavours.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

355ml bottle. From Alko. 
Poured near black with a thick off white head. 
Oat, roasted malt, licorice, chocolate. 
Quite smooth mouthfeel. 
Flavor has roastedness, licorice, cold coffee and mild chocolate. Tasty, abv nicely hidden.

0,355l bottle from Alko, Keljo. Pours very dark brown with a low tan head. Aroma is roasted malts with some chocolate. Flavor is roasted malts with some chocolate, some coffee, some ashtray, alcohol and hops. Very good.

1 finger offwhite head that leaves lacing.
Pitch black beer. 
Aroma is dark roasted coffee, sweet liquorice, bitter dark chocolate and also some vanilla, sourdough bread and vinous tones as it warms up. Not strong enough aroma to be a 8 but close!
Taste is smooth chocolate, salty peanuts and coffee with a pleasant bitterness and a warming boozyness at the back, unfortunately is loses a lot of flavor as it warms up, which brings it down a point.
Sadly thinner than I would like but sticks and lingers in the mouth for a long time, which is great. 
Overall a good impy that wouldve gotten a higher score if it was thick as motor oil, held its flavor for a longer time and was a bit stronger & heavier but still superb, would recommend and buy again, as long as you drink it rather fast.

Bottle. Black in color with a tan head. Roasted coffee, some light smokey notes and bitter chocolatey vibes in aroma. Minerals, salty licorice and smokey notes in taste. Dark chocolate and bitter notes in finish. Quite soft and smooth when warm enough.

Black with a light brown head - Roasted malt aroma with some coffee notes - Roasted malt body with some coffee notes and a nice bitterness - The roasted malt goes into the finish with bitterness - This was good

Aroma; black malts, roasted malts, black caramel, liquorice, leather. Look; light brown layer, black body. Taste; roasted malts, liquorice, yeasty prunes, black caramel, juicy cocoa chocolate - leading to a mocca finish. Feel; solid body, soft, nice. Overall; very likeable. Very nice. Smoky, roasty, chocolately... plenty of hop presence... lingering roasty bitter finish. Lovely.
Sample at the brewery. Low fluffy lasting brown head. Pitch black body. Mildly smoked roasted malt coffee aroma and flavor with a fair amount of hops bitterness, low carbonation and a long finish.

A deep black & headless stout with a medium body & soft carbonation. Aroma is rather uneventfulsmoky (roasted malts + Italian roast coffee) and faintly sweet. Tastes similar with smoky malts, cocoa, & coffee up front; sweet licorice middle; finishing dry with bitter espresso. Drinks so smooth and easily for 8.5%. Not bad but nothing special either.

Clear, black body with a small, brown, rather short-lived head that leaves some lacing on the glass. Dark roasted malty and strong aroma of dark chocolate, chocolate sauce, coffee and leather. Strong flavour of dark roasted malt, coffee and liquorice, with chocolate, brown sugar and hints of anise seeds in the back. Moderate sweet taste with a moderate bitter long-lasting finish. Full body, creamy and softly carbonated. Very nice! 
[35.5 cl bottle, enjoyed 1 year 4 months after bottling, from Systembolaget Kungshamn, Sweden]
Nästan svart öl med ett mörkbeige skum. Doft av rostad malt, choklad och kaffe. I smaken tillkommer viss vanilj, hasselnötter och lite lakrits.

Lukt: Røste malt, kaffe og lakris.
Utseende: Sort.
Skum/kullsyre: Tynt skum.
Smak: Røsta malt, kaffe, lakris og mørk sjokolade.
Hvor: Mellombels, Bryne.

Deep brown color, light brown head. Coffee nose, roasted malt, brown sugar, anise, sweet notes. Roasted malt taste, sweet, coffee, licorice, caramel, bitter espresso finish. Medium body, soft carbonation, velvety mouthfeel.
Flaska från SB. Smak och doft av choklad, fina kaffearomer, lakrits, karamell med toner av brunt socker och lakrits samt aningar av rök. Bra balans, fin sötma, komplex, rund och len, Mycket gott!

Deep black with medium light brown head. Aroma is coffee and dark chocolate. Some phenolic licquer. Slightly hoppy nuts as well. Taste is very bitter with some chocolate sweetness and a nutty creamy texture. Heavy and nice. Smooth stuff.

Bottle. Yes, it is black, brown lace. Strong roast notes, a hint vegetal, honey roasted cereal, medium light body, slick, Ethiopian coffee fruity coffee notes, dark sugar, milk sugar body, a hint smoke, Very neat!
Bottle. Black color with beige head. Aroma is coffee, roasted, a bit lacto. Taste is roasted coffee, ash, burnt wood, dry. Smooth mouthfeel. Awesome!

355ml bottle. Pitch black with small brown film. Aroma of liqorice, chocolate, roasted malts, coffee and a light spiciness. Taste is dry with roasted malts, light liqorice, coffee beans, cocoa, a light spiciness and a very light hint of smoke. Dry medium mouthfeel, light carbonation and dry coffee bean aftertaste.

355ml bottle bought from djoeye. Pitch black in the glass, shiny naked surface, scattered lacing. Attractive aromas of dark chocolate and liquorice, moderately roasted. Confectionery flavours joined by liquorice and backed by dark fruits. Bittersweet malty ending, lingering for quite a while. Fine bodied. Good drinking on a Saturday eve. (Tromsø 03.09.2016).
355ml från systembolaget. En riktigt trevlig och lättdrucken Stout som inte smakar alkohol trots 8,5 %

3 finger tan head, black body. Nose: Filter-coffee, licorice, soy-sauce, smoked notes and chocolate. Taste: Ferry-coffee left on the plate all day, burnt sugar, caramel, brown sugar, malt, toffee, chocolate, licorice and soy-sauce. Long bitter ending.

Pours black with a medium foamy tan head. Aromas of rich dark chocolate, pumpernickel, roasted malt, roasted nuts, brown sugar, slight notes of dark red berries. Taste is chocolatey and nutty with sweet lactose notes and some bitterness. Mouthfeel is luxuriously creamy and substantial with moderate carbonation.
Bottle from SB. Very dark brown with a medium tan head. Malty and roasted tones. Malt, coffee, fruit and bitterness. Medium to full body with a nice roasted / bitter finish.

Bottle 355ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, alcohol, licorice, caramel and coffee. Taste is medium sweet and light to medium bitter with a long chocolate, licorice and coffee finish. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Drank with Bram, Rik and Lennart at the Hopfen & Malz bar. Roasty, carbonation and a good body. Plenty of taste. Good beer.
300ml bottle at Taphouse Munich. Aroma is toffee and coffee. Appearance is black with a brown foam. Taste is light sweet and bitter. Amazing.
Dark brown/black color. Aroma is lot of roasted malt, some coffee, small licorice. Roasted flavor with coffee and licorice. Bitter roasted malt during the finish.
Bottle at BD57, february 17th 2016. Black body with a small tanned head. Aroma of burned malt, wood, chocolate. Taste is quite malty and sweet, ashes and dark chocolate. Good bitter warm finish.
Jet black, cappuccino colored head. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, roasted nuts. Same sort of taste but now with vanilla and minty notes. A slightly bitter astringent bite towards the end. Good stuff.
355ml bottle at Beer Station, Xiamen. Pours black with a thin off white head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Hint of milk. Bittersweet finish. Nice.

Bottle. Black with ring. Dark chocolate aroma with some roasted coffee. Sweet dark chocolate roasted coffee some dark fruit, licorice and spice with roasted espresso bitterness. Earthy. Medium full oily body. Very sweet and slick. Pretty good.
Nice black pour with almost no head. Smells of chocolate/coffee/malts. Big flavor of bittersweet chocolate and a little smoke.

Bottle. Aroma is dark chocolate, cocoa powder, fat milk, hints of vanilla, some toffee. Black, small beige head. Medium sweetness, low bitterness, taste is dark chocolate, cocoa, some coconut, hints of coffee. Medium body, soft carbonation, oily texture, medium long finish with hints of bitterness and astringency. Very nice!

Draught @ Taproom Malmö, Bergsgatan 33, Malmö, Sweden 21422. [ As Left Hand Fade To Black Vol. 1: Foreign Stout ].Clear dark black brown color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly to fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, coffee, sweet malt. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet with a long duration, sweet malt, caramel, chocolate, sweet chocolate, coffee, roasted, dark malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20160123]

Pitch black color. Very rich nose of licorice, dark chocolate, dark fruit and tobacco leaves. Medium body tons of roasted malt, slightly sweet, lactose, treacle. Alcohol well hidden. Rich. Long finish with dark chocolate and dark fruit. Very nice

Definitely a solid performer, but didn't taste the favors that were touted in the deScription, and wasn't as smooth as I expected

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Le Petit in Shimokita. Pours a black to deep brown with a finger of beige foam that lingers. Big roasted malt aroma with some peppery hops, cacao, espresso and some toasted caramel. Roasted sweet notes on the palate. Good carbonation with good roasty, hoppy bitterness. Almost like a big, bold black IPA. Nice bitter espresso notes that linger on the finish. Tasty.

Decent, but not THAT good. Quite standard.Black color with a beige layer on top. Some lacing. Ok intensity in the aroma. Solid body and a soft carbonation. A fine bitterness to balance up the sweetness. Dark malt, chocolate, coffee and some earth. [On tap at Café Sara in Oslo, Norway]

Off the top of my head Im thinking this is probably the best offering Ive enjoyed from Left Hand Brewing! I would gold star it. I am happy with everything about this one...I will be drinking more of it for sure! Wonderful strong espresso with perfect sweetness.

The Foreign Extra Stout is a niche style thats close to traditional imperial stouts, but theres a finite difference between them. Id say Left Hand Fade to Black, Volume 1 is a good example of the style and I could tell it was a FES right away. Stylistically its on-point in all aspects, and as a beer its really tasty and nice to drink.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a wine glass. It had a best by date of 10/27/16 and cost $2.29 ($0.19 per ounce).

Appearance: Despite the name its actually a deep dark brownish red hue. Not completely opaque. Pours to a small, tan, foamy head which laces and retains fairly well.

Smell: Plenty of dark roasted malt as well as sweet confectionery notes of toffee, treacle and molasses. No alcohol presence.

Taste: A bit mild up front, but plenty of roasted malt flavor and dry coffee-like bitterness at the apex. The finish is the best part as it changes on a dime from bitter to sweet. Just like the aroma, the palette is pretty rich with toffee, treacle and molasses. It leaves an aftertaste of syrup, though the hops linger as well. I get some dank piney hop character throughout, which is nice. I would consider this to be a pretty well-balanced brew. 

Drinkability: At 8.5% ABV, Left Hand Fade to Black, Volume 1 is actually bit big for the style, though it seems much lighter than the average imperial stout. The alcohol never comes through in the aroma, taste or body. The mouthfeel is not quite the sticky sensation you might think; full-bodied for sure, but still quite crisp with a smooth finish. Not quite a liquid dessert, though Im sure itd pair well with your favorite chocolate or vanilla treat.

RATING: 8/10

Taste is moderately roasted, burnt caramel, some peat, cocoa beans and light smoke. The alcohol is very well hidden. Becomes sweeter as it warms. Well made and nicely balanced. Much tastier than their Imperial Stout for sure.
Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights. Medium white head. Aroma is strong coffee. Flavor is burnt malt and toffee. A decent stout, but nothing to write home about.
caramel, roasty, coffee, black, minimal head, brown foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, soft carbonation, long finish,
Wow, really liked this. Great flavor. Deep, dusky, bright with bite and sour. Excellent. Not incredibly complex, but a joy to drink.

Very dark on the pour with ruby-coloring around the edges; head is tan.  Great aroma to it with lots of chocolate and toffee, also very roasty. It tastes like it smells, and thats a good thing. I was pleasantly surprised with this beer overall and it is a great example of an export stout, not as sweet or boozy as imperials but a little bigger than your typical dry stout

Bottle via rlmartin, i think.  Pours dark but with evident ruby highlights.  Head was tan but a little too wet to lace.  nose was roasty and chocolaty for the most part.  Flavors were like powdered cocoa with a bit of roasted malt upon a lighter feeling body and seeming to hide the alcohol completely.    Clean, roasty, chocolaty stout, but nothing comes across as interesting, per se.

Pours a deep brownish/black color with a medium tan head.Aromas of roasted malts,coffee and some chocolate.Flavor matches the aroma,but it has a big bitter bite to start that fades into a roasted smokey finish.Body is medium.Not too bad!

Served from a 12 oz bottle of volume 1 courtesy of awiseman01. Pours a deep brown with a small tan head. Sweet roasted malts, buttered popcorn, and touches of coffee to the nose. Flavors of roasted malt, over cooked popcorn, toffee, rootbeer hard candies, coffee The mouth is medium bodied and very flowing. A nice foreign stout for sure.

12 oz bottle

Discovering this lurking in the back of the cellar I immediately decided to give it a try. I have been on a bit of a stout / porter kick recently and this fit the mood perfectly. I wish that this would come back again some day but in the meantime Ill look forward to what Left Hand has up their sleeves for 2010.

Aroma / Appearance - Thick and dense the head suffocates anything beneath. A murky black body soils the sides of the glass with sheets of dirty lacing. Heavy coffee notes combine with light smoke in a way that reminds of hiking boots which have recently dried out from a muddy trip. It could be a bit more complex but overall I like what is going on here.

Flavor / Palate - The heavy chocolate and coffee notes make this taste like a rich espresso. Sticky in the throat the chewy mouthfeel and texture give you plenty to ponder. I am reminded of Southern Tiers Choklat. This could be a little less one dimensional yet I still find it very robust.

12oz bottle pours dark brown with a slight tan, diminishing head. Faint aroma of coffee, cocoa and roastiness. Caramel and toffee sweetness with roasted malt/coffee bitter balance. Lingering coffee finish. Very little (almost none) aroma/taste of alcohol. Medium body and smooth mouthfeel.

Pours black with a tan head.  Sweet aroma of chocolate, toasted malt, and a little coffee and spice.  Flavor has a lot more coffee with the sweet chocolate and toasted malt still there.  Finishes a little smoky.  Nice medium body and lively carbonation hides the alcohol content well.  I really like this one.  I am looking forward to seeing what they do next year.

Poured dark brown with lighter red coming in around the edges.  A short tan head appeared and produced very little lacing.  The aroma was chocolate, roasted malt, licorice and some soft spice like nutmeg.  The flavor was spice and licorice with mild chocolate and coffee.  Thin to medium in body.

Bottle. Poured black with a tan head that settles to a ring and left light lace. Aromas of chocolate, roast, and coffee. The flavor was like coffee ice cream with a roasted malt backing. Full body, tingly carbonation, and a light roast aftertaste.

Lefthands best beer to date.  You will find alot of roasty, chocolaty, coffee undertones to this one, and by the way... where is the alchohol?!?!  This beer went down way to easy, and actually brings a tear to my eye knowing that I have too wait for winter to arrive to be able to it again.  Great beer.

Draft on tap at Bavarian Lodge (Lisle, IL). Pours an opaque black pour, pitchblacn, a small light brown head that is a thick film, stays that way, laces ok. Aromas are dark and roasty, a firm roasty malt base leading into some dark chocolate, caramel malts provide some sweetness, a touch of brown sugar, light coffee. Initial is fuller bodied, medium to heavier of medium, a potent booziness and roast hit the palate, bitter chocolate, a touch of smokiness sneaks in and really does something interesting, pretty bitter end, sweetness subdues behind. Smoke lends a touch toward ash and maybe even a touch of campfire, dry roast with caramel and cocoa sticking a bit. A full flavorful foreigh stout, a bit simple for the style I think, but the faint smokiness lends an interesting take.

Very dark coffee brown. Nice head that dissapates into a thin foam ring. Smells od toasted malt and sweet chocolate. Taste is big heavy burnt malt and chocolate. Some coffee in the finish. Very impressive, I really underestimated this beer and wasnt nexpecting much when I grabbed a single of it. I love it when that happens!

bottle pours black with a medium dark tan head.  Aroma is burnt sugar, coffee, and toffee.  Flavor is full of roasty black patent, coffee ice cream, and a light vanilla note in the finish.  Good stuff.

Bottle pours deep brown with a thick khaki head that leaves some nice lacing.  Aroma is moderate roast, dark chocolate, smoke, coffee, and another reviewer called it perfectly with burnt toast.  Flavor shows the same.  Starts lightly sweet and finishes dry and ashy.  This could have been killer, just feels like its missing something.

12 oz. bottle from the Party Source.  Pours a very dark brown, near black, living up to its title, with a big tan head that laces the entire glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, burnt toast, coffee, oats, and smoked wood.  Flavor of roasted malts, coffee grounds, smoke, molasses, and burnt toast.  The smokiness overwhelms a lot, tasting burnt.  Dry, smoky finish and roasty aftertaste.  Medium-full bodied, with below average carbonation and a chewy mouthfeel.  Some underlying sweetness.  If this were less smoky or over-roasted, itd be better; still not bad.

12oz bottle from Chips in Kill Devil Hills.  Pours jet black with a nice creamy tan head and good lacing.  Aroma is full and roasty with notes of coffee and dark chocolate.  Flavor is also nice: roast, slightly bitter coffee, chocolate, and a little dark fruit.  Very tasty.  Smooth on the palate with medium-full body.  Overall an excellent beer, but Ive got to consider this somewhat of an imperial stout based on the ABV, and I dont quite think its a standout in that style.

Deep opaque brown-black body, medium clumping, tight tan head. Rich nose with roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and burnt caramel. Bitter, strangely salty and somewhat astringent body, with loads of bitter, toasty and crackery black malt character and a licoricey fruitiness. Finishes bitter and medicinal with not-too-potent alcohol. Oily. Good, if a tad too astringent.

12 oz. bottle. Pour black brown with thin head. Aroma subtle chocolate malt and very mild soy. Tastes of little coffee chocolate and mild hops. Palate is medium to thin with mild carbonation and dry swallow. This is a nice brew taking you to a simple stout in mind with the complex flavors.

I thought it was appropriate  to close out the month of March with a full bodied Foreign Stout.   Left Hands version hits the style dead on with its Fade to Black.   Chocolate, smoke, roast, medium bitterness and sweetness wrap this stout into a nice little package.   Label has a cool design and the beer inside filled my goblet with a dark body and lacing that would make any Irishman proud

Tasted from a twelve ounce bottle.  Pours an opaque black with a medium light brown head which dissipates quickly but leaves plenty of lacing.  Smells of super dark roasted malt with dark chocolate, coffee, and a hint of molasses and plum fruitiness.  The coffee and chocolate come through on the palate with the addition of anise.  There is really no sweetness whatsoever in this beer.  The alcohol is kept in check until the finish, where the heat lingers for quite a while.  The body is surprisingly light considering color and alcohol content, due to the lively carbonation.  It seems out of place.  The finish is long.  Overall, this is a solid beer, but the palate throws me off, and although the flavors are spot on, the out of balance alcohol is a negative.

Pours a nice big 3 finger mocha head. Body is black with some ruby highlights. Head retention and lacing are both pretty good and lasted throughout. 

Aroma is of roasted chocolate and caramel malts. Some coffee and chocolate are also present. No hops and very slight alcohol. 

Nice smoky taste with roasted, burnt malts and cocoa nibs. Beer is pretty sweet, Im getting toffee. Also getting an aftertaste of crayons or corn. Hops are very muted and alcohol is hidden extremely well for almost 9 percent.

Beer has a medium bodied mouthfeel. Good amount of carbonation but not too much. Head added a little bit to the consistency.  

Drink ability was great. For such a strong beer it was very sessionable. Really good beer that I look forward to trying more of, definitely recommend it.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts. Flavor is pretty sweet and balanced by roasted malts. A very drinkable stout.

Enjoyed this brew both from cask and bottle. Poured a very dark brown with a big off-white head, lots of lace.  Aroma is very roasty malty, with some notes of sweet malt.  Taste is similar with lots of big roasty flavor and some light sweetnes.  Pretty straightforward but, very well done.  Body is big and full.  Great brew.
Black with a fluffy brown head.  Not a whole lot going on, dry toasty chocolate.  Quick finish.

Deep garnet tinged dark brown body with a tall, creamy tan head.
Rich roast malt aroma that pushes up through the thick head.
Lots of roast malts that are well balanced by the underlying sweetness.
Full bodied. Very enjoyable.

Dark, creamy, sweet, chocolate, roasted malts....
Loving the sweet roasted flavors of this beer. Not a record breaker, but worth it to buy for sipping on an affordable six pack.
12 ounce pour dark pour brown head taste of coffee, chocolate, caramel, ,licorice . Great beer

Bottle; brought back from my trip to AZ.  Poured a very dark brown/black; hence the name I guess; not much light brownish head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, cocoa, smoke with some light wet and sweet notes.  Pretty complex taste; nice and full.  Roasted, toasted, meaty and smoked; some cocoa and caramel notes.  More earthiness in the finish.  Seems to get better with time, which is always a good feature.  Something about this I really liked.  Good stuff.
Dark pour with small creamy head.  Dark fruit, roasted malt, wood and nuts.  A pretty nice brew.
very dark brown, with a beige head that sticks around til the end. long lasting bitterness, huge roasted notes on the nose. not much depth. decent.

Deep rich pour. Dark. Head fades away, and is a warm off white tan color. Taste is warm with hints of chocolate, coffee and licorice. Nothing really set this stout out to me. Good beer, but probably one and done. Not sessionable.

12oz. bottle.  Roasty, sweet aroma, with notes of molasses, coffee, earth and smoke.  Clear black color, showing some dark brown when held to the light, the head slight and fading.  Flavor profile features a rather nicely balanced malt character, with plentiful dark malt sweetness and chocolate meeting a roasty, bitter, earthy, nutty, more hoppy and drying component towards the finish, along with traces of char, ash and muted hop spice.  Palate is somewhat thin, acidic, gently warming and low in effervescence, body is medium-full.   Authentic and tasty rendition of the style.  On a side note, the Metallica song of the same name typically jumps into my head when drinking or even seeing a bottle of this stuff in the cellar.

Black with a tan head which fades quickly. Nice aroma of dark chocolate on the nose, slight coffee. Flavors are the same but chocolate is more on bitter side, and again the coffee is slight but toasty, smokey as well and little bit of hops. Has a nice dry finish and body is full, creamy and smooth. Nice beer.
A full flavored and velvety stout that is very drinkable. Loads of dark chocolate and subtle hops. Coffee finish with with a warming aspect that is nice.
bottle.  black pour with thick frothy head that fades after a few sips.  aroma is roasted coffee, light raison and soy.  great body.  smooth.  chocolate and roasted malts.  very nice.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with a big fluffy light tan head that sticks to the sides of the glass. Aroma of dark roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Flavor follows with lots of bitter dark roasted malt and a bit of an acidic coffee flavor, alcohol flavor is very well hidden. Full body with average carbonation and a thick creamy mouth feel. I really like the mouth feel on this one.

On tap at Shallos (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a murky cola brown to black with one finger tan milky, foamy head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of chocolate, roast, dark fruits, light caramel and toffee. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of chocolate, roast, caramel, toffee. Medium body with a roasty malt finish.

Tap at Dunedin Brewery.  Poured a dark reddish brown color with a small beige head.  Nose is hard roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate.  Medium body with a smooth mouth feel.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, light coffee, and light smoke.  Finishes slightly acidic.

bottle consumed 12/1/2009.

clear beer but very dark... burgundy brown shade of black with a creamy khaki head and drippy lacing.

fruity aroma... maybe plums hide behind notes of smoke, roast, milk, wood, coffee and toasted nuts. 

the flavor is quite similar... ashy and slightly sour from the roast, quite woody and very dry... almost prickly it is so dry. 

the body is medium to full. the texture is sharp yet simultaneously smooth and slick. as it warms, a wet or damp mouth feel shows up. 7/4/7/4/16/3.8
Pours black as advertised with a tan head.  Superb lacing.  Aroma of roasted malts and coffee.  Flavor of roasted malts, coffee, and touch of hops.  Nice touch!  Very nice beer!

Sampled at 1702, Tucson December 2009
This arrives from the tap with a massive, almost four-finger thick, head that is light brown in color and leaves some pretty lacing on the sides of my glass.  The beer is quite dark in color, almost black, but it does have some brown hues to it.  The aroma is richly malty with roasted notes; it evokes thoughts of chocolate, coffee, toasted whole grain bread, toasted grain husks (that leans towards a toasted / roasted grassy note), hints of licorice and even a touch of sweet Bourbon and vanilla aromatics.

The taste is fairly sweet, which accentuates lots of chocolate flavors.  There is a firm roasted note in the finish that also provides to the overall bitterness, but doesnt quite balance the up front rich, malt sweetness.  The alcohol that is evident makes me thing of bourbon and vanilla flavors definitely are here, there also seems to be something like a spicy oak-quality as well.  Speakig of spiciness there seems to be a touch of something here that makes me think of chile peppers, but that might just be the influence of the garlic cheese bread that I just ate.  This has a nice creamy mouthfeel to it; this is definitely a rich and satisfying brew, though I wouldnt say it is cloying.  Hmm, there is a definite peppery note to this brew.

This is a very well balanced brew that surprised me.  It is quite tasty and definitely a great after meal type beer.  I like the spiciness and vanilla notes as these pair well with the rich Stout flavors.  The roast character is also well balanced by the up front malt sweetness.

Aroma is reminiscent of dark roasted coffee.  Beer poors black with very little tan head.  Beer has a heavy roasted flavor at the beginning that fades to coffee notes as the beer settles.  Bitterness is evident but it blends well with the bitterness of the roasted malts.  Palate is medium bodied with a somwhat astringent feeling left in the mouth after swallow.  Overall the beer is OK but not a stout I would choose over others.

Tight tan head, opaque brown in color. Thick and silky. Smoother than other foreign stouts, similar to oatmeal stout, but with a dry bitter finish and a lot more punch. Aroma of sweet and roasted malts with a sharp note of alcohol, hints of coffee and chocolate. Perfect for the cold, snowy evening were having.

Tap at Pony Bar.  Deep black pour with a large tan head.  The nose is loaded with rich dark malt.  Chocolate, molasses licorice and deep roasted black malt.  Burnt sugar and heavy char along with a bit of lighter/softer fruitiness.  What I like about this is that it manages to get a lot of deep, dark complex aromatics in a beer that is fairly light and drinkable.  Soft wheaty texture and even though its 8%, it drinks a lot lighter than that.  As it warms the chocolate and treacle character comes to the fore.  Loads of coffeeish roast and a fairly pronounced piny hoppiness.  Very interesting brew really.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2010 On tap at the Rattle N Hum. Roasty aroma, roast coffee. Slight white head, yet lots of white lace. A yeasty part that I didnt expect or like. I normally really like this style, and others do too, but I just didnt get it today.

Pours nearly opaque with generous light tan head that laces well and remains thick throughout the pint.  Nose is a big roast-monster, nothing more... nothing less.  On the palate there is a noted low carbonation but the big roasty flavors with coffee pick up center stage and carry the show.  Dont really notice much hop influence.  Finish is very roasty as well.

12oz - 2009 - Aroma is deep dark roasted malts and chocolate.  Flavor is bold yet very drinkable.  Lots of dark roasted malts, sweet chocolate and just a touch of hop bitterness.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Palate is creamy and dry.  A real nice brew.

I poured a dark cola colored brew capped by about an inch of milk-chocolate tan colored dense foam, leaving light lacing. I get a nice mild chocolate and caramel aroma with just a hint of alcohol. The flavor is smooth and straight forward, full bodied and well balanced chocolatey sweetness with mild roasted bitterness. I think the carb is just right, softening up and carrying this syrupy beer right down. VERY appreciative of the brewer for this delicious, higher gravity offering. Great brew.

12oz bottle from Sams, Durham. Far fewer Metallica references in the ratings than Id expected. Dark pour is less oily and more carbonated than Id expected. Nose is dominated by the roasted malts youd expect but theres a whiff of cola in there. Mouthfeel is smooth and lactic, with a chalky finish thats right on point for the style. ABV is well hidden, pleasantly bitter throughout, but I cant quite give this a more than solid rating.

(22oz bottle, courtesy of Swalden28)  Pours a dark brown body with a small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, cocoa, roasted marshmallow, and caramel.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, lactose, caramel, and some lightly burnt grain.

Bottle shared with maniac and numenor.  Pours a very dark clear walnut with ring of light tan head.  Nose is sweet, almost lactose, and mildly smokey.  Flavor is earthy, toffee, hazelnut, and lots of roast.  Medium body with moderately high carbonation.  Pretty good.  And cool label.

12 oz. bottle transferred to a Czech-pils glass at Lunar Brewing Co. The pour was black/brown, with thick, frothy, mid-tan foam to the head, and clingy, curtainy lacing. The aroma was very roasty, almost burnt qualities, with a malty creaminess, and notes of cocoa and light caramel. The flavor added to these a distinctly dry hop bitterness that continued into the finish. The body was medium+ with a pleasant, creamy texture. Placed 2nd out of 16 high-quality Stouts at this years Shoot stOut competition put on by Lunar Brewing Co., Villa Park, IL.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with a tan head that settles to a thin film.  Aroma is of Malt o Meal Coco Roos and it reminds me of Northfield, MN.  Some coffee and dark roasted malt also make their presence known.  Bit of chocolate and a lightly tart/sourness is also present in the aroma.  Gets vegetal too.  Taste of dark chocolate, roasted malt, smoke, salt, and peanut butter.  Mouthfeel is full and carbonation is a touch high.  Pretty good stuff.

Pours very dark brown with a dense dark tan head.  The aroma has dark roasted malt, dark chocolate, cream, licorice and is nicely bitter and smooth.  Medium / thin body that starts smooth and silky and ends up crisp and sharp with a light carbonation to it.  There is a real snap to it at the end.  The flavor starts with the malt and chocolate from the aroma with some dark berries and is quite dry and bitter.  The finish has some char that comes through.  Very nice beer.

tap @ Rattle n Hum - Dark brown/black pour with some red highlights. Head is small and tan. Huge arouma of coffee, nuts, almonds and butter. Roasted chocolate malts with springy carbonation. Theres some astringency in there, but its not too unpleasant. Creamy body, thick mouthfeel. some molasses and brown sugar notes. This is my kind of beer.

Bottle.  Unimpressive pour... looks more like a cola or rootbeer than a stout.  Lots of fizzy carbonation sticking to the side of the glass and a bit of a fizzy head.  Aromas are alright, but not too terribly exciting, either.  A bit of an earthy and coffee-like maltiness with a little bit of a tanic aroma to it, kind of like wet oak leaves or something.  Flavor is much more interesting than either aroma or appearance.  A pretty well developed chocolate presence throughout, with some peat-like earthiness and a little bit of a creaminess.  In spite of the rich flavors, this is pretty thin on the tongue.  Good stuff once you get past the front door.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: I had heard quite a bit of hype for this so i was very curious, picked up a sixer at roof bros in paducah, ky. Pour is black with brown head, looks like a stout should. The flavor is more complex than your average foreign stout, I really enjoyed this smooth and very drinkable brew and i killed the six pack in a night!

The aroma is burnt coffee malt. Nutty toffee and caramel. Hazelnut and brandy, bourbon whiskey.

Appears jet black. Creamy, puffy light brown head. Intimidating.

The flavor is supremely bitter. Burnt coffee and cookies. Nutty with some nutmeg and toffee sweetness. A bitter finish. Hints of chocolate and charcoal. Mocha.

Feels thick and oily but with a gritty tension to it. Strong, challenging, outstanding.
Dark brown with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate. Sweet flavour with hard roasted malt, dark chocolate and espresso notes. Finished sweet.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a small white head. Aroma is dark roasted and breadish malty. Lingering roasted and dark malty flavoured. Light sweet and dark roasted note. Dark roasted and mild acidic note into the finish.

Bottled. Dark brown coloured with a reddish gleam. Light brown head. Aroma of cocoa, light roast, sweetness, some fruits,  spice. quite complex. Flavour of cocoa, chocolate, light liqourice, roast, syrup, brown sugar and spice. Medium to full bodied. Roasty chocolaty bitterness in the end. Very nice. Thx. to Santa mike for this.

Bottled. A deep red beer with a huge brown head. The aroma has notes of caramel, malt, and flowers. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, nuts, and a bit of wood, leading to a dry alcoholic finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of madsberg. Clear reddish brown head and a small beige head. Sweet hard roasted malt in the nose. Medium body, very hard roasted malt, some vanilla and licorice. Extremely malt bitter finish - not really pleasant. 080210

I had this both on tap and in a bottle. Solid black in the glass, go figure, with a nice tan head. I remember a strong roasty nose, with definite licorice and chocolate notes. The flavor, unsurprisingly, was similar, with a strong roasted malt backbone and notes of wood, coffee bitterness, and some earthy hops. Quite a pleasure to drink. Im just disappointed it came and went so quickly.

Reviewed 1/1/2010 (Bottled 10409):

Pours a nearly pitch black color body, average tan color head, diminishing.  Strong dark chocolate aroma, sweet like a milk stout.  Bitter chocolate taste. Sweet. Some bitterness on the end, but balanced pretty well.  Some bitter coffee taste on the end.  Thick, not as bitter as it warms.  somewhat chalky or something.
BQ2010. Pours a black body with thin head and slight lacing. Aroma of malts, slight alcohol, and roast. Flavor is smooth roast, some burnt wood.
$10 / sixer  This is a re-rating.  I still feel the aroma dramatically affects the overall rating of this beer, but  the flavor is really nice and dry.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown color topped by a thick, foamy tan colored head that settles to nice film leaving sheets of lace on the glass. The aroma shows notes of dark chocolate, coffee roast, some bready yeast, and a dose of earthy hops on the back end. The flavor follows with the bittersweet coffee roast, dry, dark cocoa, with a hint of caramel malt to add some sweetness. The yeast adds a nice dryness to the flavor and the earthy hops give it a nice bitterness on the backend. Medium bodied with balanced carbonation that sports a dry, roasty finish. I really liked the flavors in this one. Really nice take on the style.

12 oz bottle from Leukens Dunedin.  Pours opaque black with tan head.  Nose is roast, earth, black coffee, black licorice, and maybe some unsweet chocolate.  Flavor is very similar with noticeable roast, licorice, and black coffee throughout.  Some dark chocolate comes about mid-swallow.  For an export stout, this medium bodied bear is pretty good.

Tap at Blind Tiger. Pours a dark brown with a firm, tan head. Nose is roasted malts. Flavor is keen on the malts with some spice presence. Full-bodied and satisfying. More mild roastiness on the finish. Really good. More complex than a typical dry Irish stout without going over the top. One could certainly drink a few of these end over end.

Bottled. Filtered deep brown pour with a small, tight head. The aroma is pungent, spongey, vegetal, with mild roast, chocolate, winter squash. The flavor is similar up front, but has a perfectly chocolatey and roasty early finish with a lingering cocoa and vegetal sweetness in the back. Easy drinking and gentle, though there is a bit too much sweet corn up front for my tastes. The finish is just so good, though...

my first beer of this style. pours black, with a tight khaki head, smells like roasted malts and kind of metallic, tastes malty, with bitter chocolate on the back of the tongue, kind of burnt. and some light coffee, smooth and easy to drink, given its bigger abv. cool label too.

Multiple drafts at the Mount Holly winter beerfest. Poured a pitch black body underneath an average sized mocha colored head. Aroma was toasty with notes of dark chocolate and coffee grounds. Flavor was great, coffee, dark chocolate, burnt toast, roasted malts. Awesome beer that I will buying more of.

I had this on cask at the Atlanta Cask Ale Festival. This was one of the few that was just served straight up and not with a lot of funky additions. Nice roasty aromas and flavors with a pleasant sweetness.
Sampled at High Street Grill Winter Beer Fest. Real nice potent brew with a pretty balck color and tan head. Chocolate and coffee dominate the nose and flavor. Crisp finish for the style.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a brownish black with a thin tan head that quickly diminishes to a thin film that leaves a touch of lacing.

The aroma is sweet grains, lactose, chocolate, tobacco and roasted malts.

The flavor is roasted malts and chocolate with a little lactose and coffee.  It has a tarry bitter finish that is almost mouth-puckering.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, a decent foreign style stout.  A little on the tarry side for me.

Pours an opaque black color with a light brown head. Aroma is roast, chocolate, brown sugar, toast, and slightly earthy. Flavor is chocolate, toast, chocolate, caramel, some smoke, and a bitter spicy finish.

Tap at The Diamond. Pours a light black with a big beige foamy head. Nose is coffee and roasted malts.  Its a thin mouthful that almost reminded me of iced coffee. The front starts mild with some
coffee notes, then continues with more coffee and a bitter finish. That was the impression with it being served quite cold. Having read the commercial description, its sort of like a winter beer that is gettjng ready for summer. Pretty good.
POurs deep black.  Has notes of licorice up front.  Dry dark chocolate and a roasted coffee mouthfeel drive through the finish.  Cool stuff.

Pours a transparent dark mahogany with a small, spotty-lacing light beige head.  Aroma of sweet dark caramel and milk chocolate with some raisin and brown sugar notes.  Starts with good fullness and sweet brown sugar and molasses with some earthy bittering hops and a rich, roasty dark malty finish.  A pretty smooth and true to style foreign stout.

12oz bottle pours very dark with edges of dark brown and thin tan head. The aroma is sweet with a mix of dark ripe grapes, black licorice, chocolate malts, dark roasted malts and sort of earthy fig skins. The taste seems similar with robust sweet ripe dark grapes, Concord grape jelly, prunes, chocolate malts, dark roasted malts, a touch of burnt malts and a thin layer of molasses. It stays chocolaty with a touch of roasty dryness into the finish. Nice.
Black color/ tan head. Dark cocoa, sour dough bread aromas. medium body. Dark sour dough bread flavors with a mild, sweet black licorice herbal taste, bitter bakers chocolate.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours solid black with a frothy creamy brown head. Aroma of roast malt, milk chocolate, vanilla, toasted bread. Taste is a medium sweetness with bitter cocoa. Medium body, smooth milky texture.

Roasted aroma with notes of coffee and dark chocolate. Flavor is very roasted, with coffee, roasted nut, chocolate and a bitter hop finish. Alcohol is very warming, but not over-powering. Body is moderately thick. A tasty wintertime stout.

Got to try this on tap this past weekend at the Great Alaskan Beer and Barley Wine Festival in Anchorage, AK. Colour... black with a thin tan head. Nose... roasty malt with some coffee and sweet dark chocolate. Palate... a burst of CO2, roasted malt, coffee, dried chicory root, Postum, dark chocolate and a long roasty finish.

Nose of cocoa, milk, oatmeal.   Pour is dark with a medium tan head.  A better than average imperial stout.  Nothing that sets this apart, but it is very drinkable and fits very well into the foreign stout category.  One of Left Hands better offerings.

12oz bottle.  This is a pretty nice Stout.  Deep black-red-brown color, not unlike a deep, opaque Porter.  Minimal head.  Lots of coffee, could easily be dubbed an Imperial Coffee Stout.  Smooth and creamy, with the dry bitterness of the coffee solidly imbedded all over the palate.  Surprisingly easy drinking, with no minimal alcohol warmth or excessive stickiness.  There is a sugary sweetness, certainly thick and rich, full bodied all the way.
Good beer. I like the different style. Sweet stout with a creamy head. Caramel with a hint of molasses sweetness. Worth trying. Left hand is a good brew co.

Black, brown edges, grayish tan carbonation. Dry roast, bittersweet chocolate, milk chocolate, dried dark fruits, graham cracker. Subtle licorice on the finish. Medium body, softly balanced, finishes a bit drier than expected. With a lower abv it would be a solid session stout.

This is one of my favorites. The aroma is of roasted coffee, molasses and dark cocoa. Pours dark brown with a light tan head and a nice lacing. Flavor is rich and toasty with a slight sweet start and a strong coffee and slightly bitter finish.

Pours black with a light brown head which quickly dissipates. The aromas are a little vanilla, dark fruit, a little cherry tartness, coffee and chocolate. The palate is light and oily and the taste works in three ways: initially sweet, moving to a kind-of tartness, to a very coffee ground-bitter and lasting finish.  This is a complex stout worth a try.
The aroma is dirty but has some coffee and chocolate as well as burnt malt. The appearance is brown with a thin head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is thin. Overall this is an average beer.
gives a bunrt aroma and taste, it is weak on the palate. the is bitter coffeeand toasted malts. little hops but still drinkable

Pours a black color but you can see some red hues if you hold it to a light.  No head on my pour at all.  Aroma seems thick and full of molasses.  A hint of roast, chocolate and coffee.  Taste starts a little sweet and finishes a little astringent.  If you let it linger you get some hop bitterness, coffee grounds and chocolate malt.

interesting stout. As dark a black color as one can get with no head to be seen. The aromas was some dry bread and coffee. Had some sweetness on the taste and even some fruit. Had an overall impression of cereal. Interesting stout.

What is this? Do I deserve such consecutively good beers like the ones Ive been having? I would say yes to that, and yes that everyone deserves good beer all the time. Well then... Pitch black, density-unknown but pretty damn thick and well ladies and gents, this is what you want in a foreign stout- burnt toast, ashey, smokey and rich with chocolate infused alcohol. Has bitterness but i wonder if its from those damn hops or maybe something else. Does have a bit of bark-i-ness to it. Fantastic bier from LH. Most of the others have been mediocre at best. This is great :)

The aroma is burnt, ashy, maybe a hint of chocolate, not very sweetor enticing.  The appearance is true to the style, deep brown, reddish hue, thin tan head.  The flavor is burnt malts, coffee, milk chocolate, nicer than the aroma.  A little bit of smoke as well.  The finish is piney hops.  The mouthfeel is medium to thick, creamy.  Very good palate.  Overall a decent stout, if not really perfect.

Tap at Pony Bar: Near black pour with a khaki head. Tarry black malt aroma- some anise suggestions with some thick dark cocoa and rummy notes. A touch too carbonated for the style. The flavor has a robust black malt presence- some spicy anise like notes and cinnamon subtleties. Smooth roast throughout. Finishes clean with only a touch of fruity notes. Not bad- would probably be better on a fresh cask (less carbonation).

courtesy of ridley
pours dark brown, mocha head
aroma, chocolate malts, light roast and mild smoke
flavor, interesting smoky palate quickly follwoed by a touch of hops but still retains a good stout character with malts and hints of chocolate. Mild dark fruit, possibly lactic notes and light bitter hop finish. 
Really innovative beer, feels nothing like a 8.5% brew.

Rich, strong, smoky aroma has tones of chocolate, fine coffee and molasses and just a shade of sweetness - very tempting and inviting. It pours an opaque sable that is just a red tomcat whisker above black and has a fairly thick and fine-bubbled light tan head. Flavor is absolutely fabulous - rich and mouth-filling, mainly fine roast coffee, unsweetened chocolate and molasses with a whisper of licorice. Texture is strongly fizzy and tingly, yet smooth and sublime. A must for anybody who loves stouts!

"Volume 1, Foreign Stout: Midnight body with a lasting 1/4" brown head and great lacing. Heavy roast aroma followed by milk chocolate, wood and light smoke. Theres a great mild meatiness going on in the aroma that really peaked my interest. Feels exceptionally malty and is a filling brew. Balanced with a slow bitter kick. The smoked meat really flourishes in the flavor and leads into a big milk chocolate and buttered toast taste coupled with green hops, molasses and a touch of anise. This is an outstanding stout, I really enjoy the smoky accents coupled with the chocolate. Well done."

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a dirty tan head.  Nose is coffee, cocoa and grass.  Creamy, not quite full body, with a tang.  Taste is bittersweet chocolate, dark roast and salty licorice.  Finishes with some grapefruit peel.

This one is right up there with the rest of them. Has an aroma of chocolate and coffee grind. The after taste really lingers in the mouth for a while, turning from biter sweet to sweet. Pours jet black with an off white khaki foam head.

Smells like coffee and it has  an alarming black pour. No head and there is no gunk on the bottom of the bottle either. Strong and bitter but its funny how the taste of this stuff develops. It is just coffee like at first then it starts to overwhelm the palate with these big volatile flavors somethng like impy stout and such. I wonder why impy stout and bitter foreign stout are not really the same thing because this certainly is on par with big bad lion stout, somewhat like expy and any other forry or impy stout out there. High alky impact is dizzying to the senses in big gulps.Not a whole lotta carbonation in there. Roasty carbonized wood seems to poke thru at times after each glug. Does not come across as strong as the ABV may indicate. An intersting call between stronger sweet stouts and imp stout, wew.   Long bitter coffee finish.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: draft @ redlight redlight.  Chocolate and coffee on the nose with a grainy malt aroma.  Pours black with a solid off white head.  Coffee liqueur right off the bat, hints of milk chocolate , malty and molasses with grassy hops.  Overall a little sweet but it is a foreign stout.

Almost black pour with a tan head.  Rosty aroma with some light coffee notes and a cedary hop note.  Flavor is a bit dry, roasty, coffee with a light hint of molasses. Very nicely done for the style indeed.

12oz. bottle served in a shaker pint. Cool label graphics. Poured a deep black with a finger of tan head. Pretty fragrant with lots of roasted barley and chocolate. Solid medium body with a smooth mouthfeel. Some malt sweetness to begin. Plenty of roasted malt bitterness along with some hops. Really long dry malt finish with lingering coffee flavor. Nice beer.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of cereal, nutty and molasses, herbs for the hops, light dough and broth for the yeast, and hints of raisin and tar. Head is small, thin, brown with some slippery lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is clear dark brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy and has a soft carbonation with a lightly astringent finish. Im not too familiar with Foreign Stouts and their attributes, but this was a pretty good beer.
Pours a lasting beige head with a dark brown body.  Aromas of coffee, cocoa, roasted.  Flavor is the same but with more roasted flavor.  Mouthfeel is silky but a little thin.

Heavily roasted aroma, bordering on ashen. Dark brown-black pour, modest tan head, temporary lacing. Flavor full of licorice-heavy roasted malt elements, dry, has the creaminess of a milk stout without the sweetness. Bitter edge to the finish. Full bodied, very smooth on the palate. Fine beer although more burnt than I prefer my stouts.
On tap at Mexican Food Factory Marlton, NJ. Extremely well balanced stout, lots of roasted malt in both aroma and flavor. Notes of bitter baking chocolate.
