Tried this beer while on Beer Quest 2010 with the guys. This was beer number 39. Pours black. Little head. Minor lacing. Aroma of malts, alc., and roasts. Flavor is smooth roasts.

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Three Cellars in Franklin, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-clear cola brown colored brew with a thick beige head that quickly dissipates to a film top. Aroma of toasted dark malt, a hint of coffee and dark chocolate, some cotton candy and some peach. Taste is full bodied, thick and slightly metallic with flavors of molasses, toasted dark malt, some coffee, chocolate and burnt wood. Finish has a mild bitterness with a coffee and molasses aftertaste that slowly disappears.

Pours dark w/ a textbook head that lingers. A high roast component on the nose is delightful. Medium full nectar w/ creamy effers. A thick malty backbone w/ spoonfuls of bitter cocoa and coffee w/ a mild sweetness factor and a fist full of hops. The finsh lingers and bitters well. Awesome balance. Trump!
Pours black with tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and chocolate. Burnt malt flavor with some bittersweet chcolate and a slightly ashy finish. Medium body with mild carbonation.

Bottle.  This beer pours red ... just kidding, its black (duh).  Not much of a head on this.  Nice cozy aroma of roasty malt.  Drinks with a very dry character, almost cloying.  Sweet and vaguely chalky, this is a nice bitter stout.  (#3786, 1/3/2010)

2009 version..lets get ill! .. had at the Houston Flying Saucer 2009 X-mas Party .. . lacing is pure excit! .. . so wonderfully roasty .. nice burnt flavors, a great interpretation of a foreign stout!!
Oh my this is good stuff! Jet black thick pour with no head. Nice roasty smell and taste. Great balance, hope I can find MORE!

On tap at Capital Ale House - Downtown on 11/30/2009. Clear dark black body with ruby highlights and a medium creamy dark tan head. Sweet roast, caramel, and light chocolate flavor. Medium full body with moderate carbonation.
Love this seasonal. Its got a roasted nutty aroma with a deep, black pour. Very thick and tastes like it smells, very woody and malty with notes of roasted chocolate and spice.

12 oz bottle. Pours deep brown nearly black with ruby hues. Aroma very sharp roasted malt, really nutty, cocoa powder, and some coffee notes. Pretty standard for the style. Flavor starts with a basic chocolate malt and cocoa character, picking up a sharp bitterness mid swallow and giving way to a bit of espresso and bitterness in the finish. Medium body and a light fizzy carbonation. Not bad, eh, not standing out to me though, thinner bodied.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 12oz bottle pours dark brown with a slight tan, diminishing head.  Faint aroma of coffee, cocoa and roastiness.  Caramel and toffee sweetness with roasted malt/coffee bitter balance.  Lingering coffee finish.  Very little (almost none) aroma/taste of alcohol. Medium body and smooth mouthfeel. The best beer by Left Hand that Ive been able to try.
Sampled at Grapes of Mirth.Poured a gloomy evil black.Nose was chocolate and coffee with creamer.Flavor was sweet,milky chocolate and roasted coffee.Finished off slightly bitter

12oz bottle.  Small beige head atop clear red-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, caramel, some bittersweet chocolate, light toffee.  Taste is moderately sweet, coffee/roast, earthy, some burnt, light bittersweet/milk chocolate.  Smooth medium-full body, light acidity.

Pours pitch black with nice big brown head.  Chocolate, pepper, roast, coffee and a hint of wet wood.  Flavor has a ton of chocolate, good roast, touch of espresso and a pitch of white pepper round out this fine ale from Left Hand.
Pours black with an off white head. Dry coffee, chocolate aroma. Coffee, chocolate malt, lactose taste, very dry. Stays true to the foreign stout style, very good.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a fading mocha head , with a bit of lacing, nose is heavy coffee, lighter chocolate, toffee, nice burnt and smoky body, mild hop spice,taste is coffee, toffee, bit of cocoa, finishing with a lingering coffee-hop bitterness...mouth feel is thick and creamy, carbonation is medium. Over all this is a rich thick Stout....Love the name too.

12 oz. from Bruisin. The pour is near black with a well formed head and good lacing in the tulip glass. The aroma is roasty enough with hints at wood, chocolate, coffee, and a fair amount of hops. It is more sour than Id like a stout to smell, but not bad. The beer tastes pretty darn good. Its dry with a firm earthy base and bittersweet dark chocolate all around. This seems to have a similar flavor profile to their milk stout, but a little drier and less fruity. Good stout.

Bottle - Deep black pour thats slightly opaque. A nice creamy tan head sits atop this one--it looks great. Smell is fairly dry, with a little smoke, a little chocolate, and some soy sauce. Taste is dry and bitter, with a nice roasted malt bite. Its a little meaty, with those same smoke and soy sauce notes from the nose. Smooth, creamy, and with just enough body, I thought this was really solid. The best part was my mom picked it up for me for Christmas because she thought the bottle looked cool. Thanks mom!
On tap from the Gingerman in Fort Worth.  Pours black with a small, but thick beige head.  Smells like vanilla, coffee, and hazelnut.  Ridiculous coffee flavor, chocolate, and caramel.
Bottle. Black pour, offwhite head. Pours a little thin. Aroma of roast and nut. Taste is roasty, coffee, and some chocolate.

12 oz. Pitch black with a lasting quarter-inch of sticky foam. Nose is huge with roasted coffee, charred grain and earthy uric acid. Flavor is dark coffee, bitter chocolate, dark fruit, cherry and light caramel on the front. Some tingly hickory char and light sour cream finish this one off well. Heavy body is smoothly carbonated, with a light acidic tingle, and drinkably thin. Well hidden abv. Much better than the spiced crap I have sampled this holiday.

Bottle poured into a pint glass produced a finger worth of tan head that settles to a thick lace. The body of the brew is of course black in color.

The aromas of bitter chocolate and coffee are present; again mostly the roasted malts come out. The flavor is sweet chocolate, with roasted accents. It has a nice and creamy feeling body medium to full feel in my mouth with light carbonation. I love to see this on nitro.

A good stout the alcohol doesnt show at all. I think I could dink a few of these in a sitting
UPDATED: JAN 6, 2010 Bottle.  Im surprised to find out the 8.5% ABV.  Pretty easy-drinking stout, mid-way between a dry and a sweet.  Not as heavy (and also not as good) as the 9% ABV Old Rasputin.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours solid black with no head. Aroma of coffee, chicory, roasted malts, chocolate and hints of brown sugar. Medium bodied, especially for a stout; feels more like a porter in the mouth and finish. Nice, slow, roasty finish. Very good stout.

On tap at sugar maple.  Dark brown with a medium tan head, slowly dissipating.  Aroma of roasted malt, mild smoke, and a touch of chocolate.  Tastes of heavy roasted malt, smoke, chocolate and mild sweet malt as it warms.  Smooth with a very mild hop and alcohol presence.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark black with a thick tan head.  Roasty and malty with some nice smoky chocolate tones.  Medium bodied, smooth, a touch of sweetness.  Finishes up with the faintest warming alcohol, nice smooth roast and toast, little bit of caramel.

On tap at the Crescent Moon, A very delicious beer. Pours black with an off white head. If I did not know better, Id say this was a sweet stout due to all the sweetness of the malt. However, theres no thin lactose sweetness. Good roastedness. I dont taste any anise, but the smokiness really emerges as this thing gets to room temperature. Its not a Bamberg kind of smoke, but it is still there.

Dark Dark brown pour.  Thin beige head and drippy lace.  Aroma is dominated by roast on the verge of being smokey.  Creamy mouth-feel.  Coffee,toasted grains, peat, and toffee.  maybe a little vanilla

Black pour with a small, loose, off-white head.  The aroma is mostly oatmeal with a balance of black coffee and dark chocolate and some notes of brown sugar and molasses.  The flavor is loads of chocolate and strong dark coffee with notes of dark fruit brown sugar and molasses.  It finishes with a lasting bitterness and a little bit of fusel alcohol.  There is a delicious milk chocolate notes that really builds throughout the glassful.  The body is oily and full with moderate carbonation.

Pours a deep dark brown, almost black color that is completely opaque with only the slightest of mahogany edges when held to a light source and a two finger frothy light tan head that quickly settles into a thick lasting ring.

Slightly roasted chocolate malt aroma with hints of burnt toast, toffee, coffee bean, oatmeal and smoke. Theres also a bit of sweet lactic creaminess present along with the deep roasted sweet bitter dark chocolate notes.

Deep roasty chewy body thats on the fuller end with a strong dark malt character, slight chocolate sweetness, lactic creaminess and a bone dry finish. Pretty complex with hints of roasted espresso bean, bitter sweet dark chocolate malt, lactic cream, burnt toast, oatmeal and toffee. Way too roasty and bone dry and not very well balanced. Theres a lot going on but only a touch of sweetness. Too one dimensional for my liking but not bad.

Bottle from ericandersnavy. Pours black with a small tan head. Aromas of sweet toasted malt and perhaps a touch of coffee. Full bodied with striking carbonation. Flavor is smooth burnt malt with a touch vanilla and some chocolate. Arguably coffee in the finish. It does end mildly astringent and a  very little bitter. Pretty enjoyable.
Rich coffee aroma with a beautiful dark almost black appearance and perfect head. The strong flavors of roasted malts and coffee are rich and smooth making this an excellent brew.

Bottle. Pours a clear, dark, chestnut brown color, with hints of darker mahogany. A thick and frothy head settles slowly to a thin but lasting blanket, leaving a dense, bubbly, sheety lace coating on the glass. The nose is really roasted, showing dark barley, bakers chocolate, and coffee, with a healthy quotient of earthen hops and toasty, bready, Belgian-esque yeast. Flavors mainly follow suit, rich, roasted, and bittersweet. Dark, dry cocoa and mocha make for the biggest component, just a touch of caramel bringing in a hint of sweetness. Earthy hops are staunch and potent, and the drying, foreign yeast falls right in line. Medium-full in body, the palate sports a prickly carbonation that gives way to a drying, somewhat ashy finish. I really dug this one quite a bit. Its a nice American interpretation of a Belgian stout.

on tap-pours a light brown head and dark brown color.  Aroma is rich dark malt-molasses/chocolate, secondary earthy hops.  Taste is rich dark malt-molasses/chocolate/ashy/burnt, secondary earthy hops.
A coffee aroma with a black colored appearance.  Medium bitter taste with a chocolate and nutty hint. Full body

Pours dark, inky brown, with a medium beige head, very fine ands lasting lacing.  Aroma of toffee, toast, nuts, and chocolate.  Medium-full body, porter-like, slightly chalky but not unpleasantly so, zesty, mildly dry.  Flavors of chocolate, molasses, coffee, toast, cashew, pepper, slightly grassy.  Medium bitter and dry finish.

12oz bottle, thanks 17thfloor! pours black with small off white head around the rim. aroma has roasted malts, coffee notes. flavors have  roasted grainy notes, a very slight sour fruit notes in there too. fizzy mouthfeel and thin-med bodied. not a bad stout.

Pours a dark black with nice carbonation and a small tan head.  Beautiful dark chocolate, coffee, light toast and a touch of toffee sweetness on the nose.  Lightly sweet with the taste of the chocolate and coffee.  Also some noticeable alcohol.  Finishes with a toasty bitterness that stays with you for a little while.  Actually lighter on the palate than the color and nose would hint at.  Fairly easy to drink even at 8.5%.

12oz bottle. Very drinkable stout. Pours deep dark black (as the name infers) with a nice creamy head and good lacing. Slight smokiness with strong malty overtones. Not spectacular but still very good
A solid if not the best effort by Lefthand.  This is truley balanced with a bit of smoke!  I note the spicy undertones and warming alcohol.  Coffee upfront leads to liciorice and smoke, well done!

From the bottle.  Before i even got the glass to my face, I immediately noted the molasses/maple syrup aroma.  As the head fades the coffee notes begin to emerge.  Pours the darkest shade of brown, with a thick and foamy medium tan head.  The bitterness of the coffee jumps out immediately, with rich earthly tones coming out in the finish.  Has a sharp, tingly mouthfeel, and oddly enough, most of the lingering taste is on the front of the tongue.   Sadly, by the time I finished this rating, the initially strong aroma had faded, but it left a surprising refreshing stout in its place.

Bottle, pours a super dark redish brown beer with  a nice tan head, lacing down the glass.  Aroma is very roasty and chocolate with notes of coffee.  A medium thick body and a bitter roast finish with lingering notes of coffee. Nice

Bottle.  Lightly roasty, lightly woody nose simply overcome with dark dryness and chocolate.  Suggestion of significant heft.  Pours darker than Coke, with a sudsy, big-bubbled, somehow highly laced light brown/tan head.  Oily light-medium body is full of flavor  chocolate cake, a little coffee, mocha dust, wood, berry.  Rich malt complexity, layers upon layers.  Well-attenuated and dry, just a bit of booze (but just the flimsy kind underneath).  Smashing success for what I hope will become a highly anticipated annual series.

nice black pour with ruby highlights when held up. Thick creamy looking head.
Aroma is quite nice, good roasted malt. dusty chocolate. A hint of earthy hop and burnt malt bitterness.
deep roasted malt leads into the flavour, a touch of dry bitterness. 
The alc is very well blended. A little thin in the body towards the finish.
Still very nice. Left Hand is starting the tradition off nicely.
Very good F Stout -- the balance of hops and smoky malts was very nice.  This had an amazing amount of flavor with a not too strong ABV- very DARK and much better than Guiness

Bottle sampled at Grapes of Mirth Winter Beers Tasting. Excellent nose of roasting nuts a hint of coffee and some bitter chocolate. Flavor was sweet cream, roasted nuts, even some toast, and a hint of chocolate. Very nice.

On tap at Ginger man FW. Smells strongly of roasted chocolate and warmth. Upfront bitter chocolate. Dries out immensely. Rich roastedness. Could use more chocolate flavoring all the way through the end.

12oz bottle.  Pours deep dark mahogany with a one finger billowy tan head that results in great lacing.  The nose is smoky dark roast coffee and cocoa.  The taste is floral hops upfront that leads to cocoa and chocolate followed by burnt malt and bitter coffee.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Pretty damn good  better than I thought it would be.

On tap at Anvil. Pours a rich dark black, with a mocha two finger head. Nose of soft hops, mocha, chocolate coffee beans and molasses. Flavors are the same, with a smooth, but flavorful medium bodied palate.

Opaque pour with a chocolate head. Rich coffee aroma and a taste that follows suit with a hint of dark chocolate. Long, lingering aftertaste. Not a bad one but it hangs around for a while. Overall, a good, not great, beer.

On tap at the Flying Saucer in KC. Pours a black body with an inch thick, very creamy, beige colored head that dissipates slowly and leaves lots of lacing. Nothing to complain about here. The aroma is sweet and roasty. Some rich milk chocolates and molasses sweetness, espresso beans and roasts, licorice, and a light dark fruit. Flavor is quite nice. Lots of rich chocolates and more of a noticable molasses sweetness throughout. A good amount of roasts keep this nicely balanced along with some espresso coffees. Licorice, some dark fruits, smoke, and a light hop bitterness complement the sweet and roasty finish while slowly drying and leaving a lengthy aftertaste. Medium to full body, soft, and very smooth. Overall, this was a very nice beer. I have had some issues with LH in the past, but I liked this one a lot. Lots of flavor and fairly complex. Nice.

12oz bottle. Poured a deep black color with an averaged sized off white head. Lacing left on the glass. Aromas of roast, chocolate,  and some lighter coffee. Tastes of the same roastiness, chocolate, coffee (stronger than the aromas), and some smokiness.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2010 (Rating #5500) Bottle This beer rocks! Pours clear and maple-colored. Sits black in my glass with a creamy, beige, everlasting head.  A decadent mélange of mocha, roasted almonds and toasted cashews is the cornerstone of the bouquet. Full-bodied and velvety with laid-back carbonation. Rich, malty, mocha and cream with moderate nickel bitterness. Bittersweet, grassy finish. Surprisingly solid world class beer!

On draught at Beerrun in Charlottesville, VA.  Beer is a dark brown/black with aromas of roasted malt and cocoa.  Tastes of chocolate malt, hops, coffee and dark bread.  Overall a fairly dark stout with nicely integrated hops keeping it balanced nicely.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Market, Charlottesville, VA. Pours a deep black color. Lives up to the name, I guess. Medium offwhite head with decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and light smoke. Taste is bitter hops in the forefront with a sweeter finish of coffee and chocolate. Some smoky and nutty notes with a strong sunflower component as well. Smooth, medium bodied. Good stuff.

Bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lasting brown head with good lacing. Aromas of bakers cocoa, charcoal, roasted malt, light plum and light coffee. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of bitter chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, light charcoal and a hint of dark fruit with a smooth dry lingering roasty finish.

Bottle from Belmont Party. Poured reddish black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted malt aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth dry texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. My expectations where met.

Bottle. Pour was dark with a dark tan head. Aroma was of light chocolate and roast. Flavor was a bit complex with chocolate, roast, toast, light caramel, and a semi-strong background of burnt malt. Nice creamy mouth feel and balance. Good brew.

Pours black into the glass with a tan head.  Aroma is roasted grain and coffee.  Hint of hops.  Flavor is dark chocolate and intense coffee flavor.  Really nice bitterness from the roasted grain.  Great  medium to full bodied mouthfeel.  Alcohol blends in well with this beer.  Love it.

12 ounce bottle - $1.99 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia. Bottled on: 11.04.09 (I assume, as the stamped mark is terribly smeared).

Appearance: Pours an appropriately black body with a fluffy, beige-colored head.

Smell: The nose starts quite dark and roasty with some humble chocolate and teeny notes of dark fruit doing their very best to temper the strongly burnt, creosote-soaked barley aroma.

Taste: Roasted, charred barley with some sweet layers of creamy, semi-sweet chocolate and dark caramel and unquestionably full-bodied coffee. Very small hint of carbonized dark fruits. Spicy, lightly earthy hops do what they can to counter the sweetness, but, really, thats already done with that deeply burnt black malt taste. Finishes dry with more than a fair share of well-roasted maltiness.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Fade to yum! This years FtB release is very roasty, sweet, and creamy -- a good nightcap for the evening a fine way to kick off this yearly series.

Tap at The Petrol Station.Pours a deep black with a nice beige head and lacing.  Aroma is faint chocolate malt.  Flavor is coffee-ground-heavy liquified chocolate powder with a nice, bitter coffee finish.  Average mouthfeel.  Nice unofficial tribute to Cliff.  Say hello to Cliff.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Pours a deep brown black with thin tan head. Nose is toasted malts, oats, maybe some wheat, mild roast and smoke. Flavor is smooth roasty malts, toast, smoke, anise.

6 pack from Mid town @ 13.99 (yikes). Our market only received 8 cases, so I thought that I would give it a try. Pours a deep coffee brown with a dissipating brown head. Aroma of dark roasted malts and coffee. Full bodied with a slick and creamy texture. Flavor of coffee grounds, molasses, chocolate, and vanilla. Average amount of residual sweetness, and slightly dry. Tamed roast bitterness on the finish. Not bad. A bit pricey though, but I have come to expect that in a state the has the highest beer taxes in the country

for what this claims to be ,it is pure excellence. One of the best new malty beers Ive had this year. Rich deep roasted aroma,with hints of powdered hersheys cocoa, one of the finest roasted aromas Ive experienced from a brew which does not claim to be a coffee stout, taste is again that dark roasted malt,maybe a hint of black patent bitterness, some of that chocolate nuance , and a ribbon of caramel that lends more taste not sweetness. Dry flavorful finish. A real Gem. THIS IS WHAT THE GUINNESS 250 SHOULD HAVE BEEN LIKE!!!

12oz bottle served in a shaker.  Slick black pour with a few ruby highlights when held up to light.  A thick head of creamy tan foam slowly settled into a lasting cap.  Heavy lacing.  The aroma included a rich, robust malt profile.  Notes of bakers chocolate, fresh ground coffee beans, and some faint fruity esters.  The flavor had chocolate, coffee, dark fruits, caramel, and some lingering bitter roast.  Medium to full-bodied with lightly crisp carbonation.  Bold but very drinkable.  I think Ill go grab another six-pack.  Well done!

i didnt expect the foreign stout classification.  The high abv is well hidden, I didnt realize it was so strong.  Roasted malt in the flavor and aroma, perhaps over-roasted.  Bitter grain, and very little in the way of hops.  Dry finish, with a little coffee.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2009 12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, light caramel, slight smoke, slight tobacco, slight tar, and slight bitter coffee.  Poured very deep brown in color with a medium-sized, creamy, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Clear.  Very slightly sparkling.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of malts, chocolate, slight bitter coffee, hops, roasting, slight caramel, slight tar, slight wood, slight smoke, and a hint of soy sauce.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Malt, roasting, hops, and tar finish is slightly dry.
bottle, thanks to swalden28, pours a dark reddish brown with beige head. aroma of coffee and caramel,  flavors  of chocolate,  burnt coffee. lasting finish

Black pour with a small tan head that dissipates into a veneer. Aroma is oatmeal sugar, roasted barley, lactic sugar, coffee, and chocolate. Flavor is quite roasty with cocoa nib, cream, dark roast coffee, and mild booze. Palate is rich, thick, and creamy in its mouthfeel. Mild carbonation yields a supper supple feel. Very interesting and well done.

Dark almost black body with a light dusting of a tan head.  Aroma has strong coffee and chocolate notes with a toasted malt character.  Body is medium with a rather carbonated mouth feel that leaves the tongue tingling.  Flavors are rather muted for such a dark beer but have notes of coffee and a strong grassy hop character.  Leaves a nice bitter aftertaste in the finish.

Dark brown/black with a thinner-than-expected tan head and nice lacing. Roasted malts and a bit of coffee in the aroma, same in the flavor with some bitter chocolate and a nice floral hop finish. Very nicely balanced for such a big stout.

12oz bottle.  Cool label.  Pours a dark shinny very near creamy black with a medium fizzy foamy light tan froth.  Aroma is crunchy and roasty, bitter coffee grounds and tons of oats, smells like a foreign stout, ashy and a touch of fruit, but mostly chocolate chip cookie.  Flavor follows, very dry, ashy, hint of fruit, a bit hoppy upfront, crunchy chocolate chip cookie, finishing with a sweet bitter dark chocolate syrup.   Medium bodied with a fuller fluffy mouth-feel, seemingly crunchy sharp fizzy carbonation, finishing very dry and ashy.  Pretty good but not my favorite style.

12 oz. bottle via trade with StFun - Pours a clear dark brown color with a one and a half finger thick tan head.   Light lacing.  Aroma is coffee and roasted malt.  Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, and herbal hops.  Finish is fairly uneventful, which is kinda nice for a big beer like this.  Medium body.  A very nice beer.  Thanks Josh.

Black, oily surface, not much head to be found. Smells a little doughy, stouty, very subtle aroma. the flavor is hard to describe, its definitely a stout but the flavors are all melded together and nothing is really distinct, muddled but tasty. Nice mouthfeel.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-10-2009 04:16:48

On tap Varga Bar.

A: Pours a lighter shade of black with a nice solid off white head. Okay retention with some nice lace.

S: Nice toasty aromas. Toasted bread, dark malt, chocolate, and coffee.

T: Black Black roasted malt. Strong notes of coffee and bitter chocolate. Mild dark fruit and a hint of smoke.

M: On the fuller side of medium. A pretty damn good beer at a pretty damn good bar.

12 oz bottle from TC Craft.  Dark roasted chocolate, coffee aroma.  Mouthfeel is a bit creamy, flavor is also chocolate (more of a milk chocolate) and bit of coffee.   Smooth creamy finish thats a little bitter.

Pours a dark black with chestnut highlights and a two finger creamy mocha hand. Nose shows lots of coffee, some bitter chocolate, roast, mild caramelly sweetness, well done dark grain character. Flavor follows suit, dark grain, coffee and bakers chocolate, sweet, a little alcohol comes in, mild fruity esters. Palate shows some roast with a little bit of alcoholic warmth and a very mild hop astringency. Pretty tasty.

Dark brown with a hint of rudy. Moderate sized tan head. Sweet grain to nearly over-ripe fruit in the nose.Husky and ashy scents as well. Smooth, full feel. Alcohol laden dark malt flavors. Really rather hard to slog down. Some more ash in the finish and linger. Likely a fairly traditional foreign stout with a light sugar adjunct. Just doesnt do much for me.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2016 Bottle (BB Aug 2017).

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is black (almost opaque, flashlight tested).

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted/burnt grain, dark chocolate), with light notes of alcohol and tar.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

Simple nose, but most of the other aspects are decent, and it seems pretty clean. Decent if not exciting.
Bottle thanks to swalden28. Pours a dark ruby pour with a beige head. Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate, nutty. Flavor is chocolate, smoke, coffee. Water mouthfeel.
Bottle. Even drinker, better as it warms. Nice semi-tart toasty dark chocolate flavor. Average aroma.

deep brown, nearly black.  small off-white head, poor showing.  acrid and rough malt nose - black patent, cream/wheat-scented yeast clashes with burnt motor oil and charred cocoa and charcoal briquettes. heavily astringent and coarse malt texture, thin and flabby body throughout with an unpleasant lactic ash note.  acrid and messy.

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Dark brown pour with a thin tan head.  Wonderful rich chocolate and smoky malt aroma.  Dark roasted malt flavor and some hints of espresso.  Unfortunately the palate is just a bit on the thin side...Ok, after letting this sit for about 15 minutes I am getting more from this beer.  The flavors are richer, the smoky chocolatey flavors are more forward, the alcohol warming is more present, and the palate is less thin.  This is a well done stout.
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma, some roast, earthy hops, yeast. Flavor, earthy, some chocolate, roast and some fruits.

Bottle from Crown#6. Pours black with brown edge, negligible head. Nose is rich coffee and dark malt. Flavor is bitter black coffee, slightly sharp and sour, spicy, roasty dark malt. Slightly thin and sticky. Not too bad.

Draft at Sheffields. Pours a deep, opaque black with dark tan head. Nose is very roasty and chocolatey with a light bite of hops. On taste, very drinkable with a ton of roasty sweetness coming through and bold burnt notes. Not really a Foreign, but a damn nice stout anyway. Good.

Black, or at least very dark brown, with a loose, foamy dark tan head. When I bought this, I thought it was Swarzbier, now I see that its a foreign stout. That makes sense. It smells black, if that makes sense - oreo cookie, coffee, a bit of dark chocolate. Flavor is pretty much the same as the aroma, but with the addition of some fruity notes. Surprisingly crisp finish, as well.

Single bottle buy from Binnys, Orland park, Illinois:  This poured a nearly opaque dark brown body with a dense tan head.  The aroma was roasty dark sweet malts with a splash of molasses.  The flavor added a touch of aniseed, roasted barley, and a woody bitterness.  Dry finish.  Actually pretty nice.
Bottle thanks to swalden28. Notes of burnt coffee, burnt brownies, dirt, and oreo cookie crust. Medium weight with a lasting finish. Nice.

Brown bordering black body with a small eggshell head that leaves nothing but a wispy reminder.  Aroma is of cocoa, roasted coffee bitterness, and ash.    Similar flavor with a little malty sweetness included.  Medium mouthfeel.  Not bad.
(bottle). Black color. Small tan head. Strong roasted malt aroma and flavor. Long duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.

12oz bottle. Pours deep black with ruby-brown highlights and a medium-thin tan head that fades quickly (though not completely - a thin tan ring remains and persists) and leaves subtle dots and legs of lace on the glass. The aroma has a wonderful buttered-toast-with-coffee sort of rich roastiness - like well-roasted freshly-ground coffee beans. There is a subtle hint of sweetness and cocoa in the aroma, too. The flavor starts roasty with subtle malt sweetness, bitter chocolate, light earthy hops, and hints of dark fruit. The fruity esters are not overwhelming, but are just noticeable enough that, combined with subtle roast acridity that almost tastes acidic/tart, give subtle impressions of raspberries near mid-palate. Mid-palate is roasty - almost burnt - with black coffee flavors and subtle toasty and chocolatey malt tones. The finish is dry and roasty with a balancing and firm earthy hop bitterness. Nearing the end of the glass, it tastes like Count Chocula cereal, but with coffee instead of milk. The mouthfeel is very roasty - almost acrid/ashy - with a nicely balanced level of bubbles and a medium-full body. There is a subtle astringency from the heavy roast that you can feel lightly coat the entire inside of the mouth -- not unpleasant, but rather hardy and bold like a Turkish coffee. Overall, a very decent export stout that is thick-thick-thick with roasted barley.
Bottle from Sams.  Pours, well, black, with small beige head.  Nose slightly smoky like a schwarz. Lots of chocolate malts as well.  Tastes similar, but with bitter ashy notes as well.  Pretty good.

12 oz. bottle thanks to good old Georgie boy.  Lots of coffee and roasted malts in the nose.  The flavor is good and exhibits the previously mentioned flavors nicely.  Just a tad of sweet condensed milk behind it.  The creaminess is there, but I would have liked to see more.  A little added complexity wouldnt hurt either, but not a bad beer at all.

Very dark brown pour with slight, tan head.  Aroma of bitter chocolate, oreo cookies, licorice.  Very strong, dry chocolate flavor. Nice mouthfeel, good carbonation, dry tasty finish.  Pretty good for Left Hand.

12 ounce bottle, bottled on November 4th, 2009.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours dark brown with about a half inch brown head that went away pretty quickly.  Lacing is good.  The aroma is molasses, coffee, smoke/burnt/charred malt, and some bittersweet chocolate.  Taste is similar to the aroma, but with a bit of licorice noticable too.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit slick and creamy with good carbonation.  Drinkability is good, its smooth and not hard to drink at all.  Also, the alcohol is well hidden.  Overall I think this is a good beer, Id buy this again in the future.  Its a good beer for a cold December day!
Bottle thanks to swalden28. Pours with a tan head with deep brown body. Aroma of smoke, leather, chocolate and molasses.  Taste is smoke, dirt and chocolate. Medium bubbles, low residuals.
Pours black with a thin and fizzy tan head.  Malty aroma with hints of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor of roasted malt with a little bitter chocolate and coffee.  Bitter finish with a bit of burn.

Wow instant display bottle.  Pours a black body with a coffee tan head.  Malty body with some dry ashen chocolate notes, a light bitter roast and a some light nutty notes.  Light warming with a dry bitter coffee finish.  Nice beer.
The body doesnt stand up to the big alcoholic bite this beer delivers.  As flavors of char, cocoa, syrup linger, a strong bitterness awaits that develops into an unpleasant boozy aftertaste.

12oz bottle from grape & gourmet. pours a deep, dark brown, damn near black with a very thin, cocoa brown head and decent lacing. aroma is very nice with notes of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, smoked wood, and a definite spicy, cigar humidor touch with a bit of raisin. flavor is damn good with big, roasted coffee with cream notes up front followed by dark chocolate, smoke, charred wood, burnt wheat toast, and nutty malts leading to a bitter, roasted coffee finish. palate is medium bodied with solid carbonation and not a hint of the 8%abv. overall, a very well done winter stout. left hand seems to on their A game recently and "fade to black" is no longer just a great metallica song.

Bottle. Jet black pour with a tall, frothy, brown head. Aroma is dusty cocoa, smoky malts, roasted notes, light coffee, burnt wood and light earthy aromas. Taste is smoky malt, burnt wood, light coffee, hints of anise, cigar ash, dark chocolate, powdery cocoa, and strong bitter notes. Body is medium to medium-full with a creamy carbonation and powdery overall feel. Ends with more smoky malt, cigar ash, wood, dark chocolate, cocoa and coffee. Rather tasty!

Black with light, fizzy brown head / Nose of cigar box and coffee / Medium body, chewy, lively carbonation with malts almost matching the good, acidic, bitter finish / Flavors of dark roast coffee with notes of unsweetened chocolate and tobacco / A very dry, acidic stout, better as it warms.
Pours medium black. Roasted nuts, toast aroma. Nice toasted malt flavors. Buttery dry. Pretty darn good.

Bottled.  Poured deep brown with a short-moderate cap of oaky-tan head.  The aroma picked up charred black patent, coffee, and chocolate maltage with an unexpectedly sweet, warm kicker on the back.. a little too much sweet and too little dry charred character, but still good.  The flavor found basically the same stuff, but with more black patent and coffee than other malts.. pine and coffee bitterness around, amplified by some boozage.. finished with lots of residual dark sugars and charred bitterness.  Medium-bodied with moderate-plus carbonation on the palate.. some dryness, but the sugars canceled out a bit too much of it.. warm, grainy finish.  This was a solid drinker that Ive now had a few of.

Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a deep black with tan head. Aroma is very nice, dark roast, a little smoke, chocolate, pepper, malt. Flavor has plenty of dark roasted malt, some smoke quality, chocolate, light grain, nice dark roasted bitter at the end. Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with high carbonation. Overall, I enjoyed this, nice tasted stout for the winter....

On tap at flying saucer. Pours a dark brown with a light tan head thag diminishes quickly leaving sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a sweet dark fruit with raisin and malt. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet fruity malt with light roast and smoke with a bitter finish. Hides the alcohol easy to drink a very good foreign stout from left hand.

Pours a deep brown to black with a light brown head. Aroma is roast chocolate barley, chocolate. Flavor is roasted malts, chocolate, barley, licorice. Medium palate nice and creamy mouthfeel with roast and bitterness in the finish. A pretty nice winter stout.
Dark black with a small but firm tan head.  Smokey roasted malt aroma with a touch of cocoa.  Dark coffee and chocolate flavor with dark roasted malt.  Full bodied with a long bittersweet finish.

Dark and almost black with a small tan head that soon becomes blotchy.  Smoke and some dark chocolate in the aroma as well as some funky fruity something.  Flavor is chocolate, coffee, milk.  Sweet, chocolaty, and a tad bit smoky describes this beer.  Easy to drink and smooth.

It doesnt say its a stout on the bottle, but after you pour it and inhale those dark chocolate aromas, you know for sure what youre about to enjoy. I tasted notes of coffee with milk and roasty nuts. This is a worthy addition to Left Hands line-up, and an enjoyable stout.

Fruity, bready and coffee aroma.  Totally balck.  medium on the palate and i a little oily and velvety.  A little sweet.  Hops are not that detectable, just faintly bitter on the finish.  The malt flavor is perfect combination of coffee, cocoa, molasses and deep roasted malts.   Unbelievable for the price.  Great value.

Pour is a black with a tan head.  Aroma is a strong roasted malt with some coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is again lots of roasted malt with some coffee and dark chocolate.  Just about everything your are looking for in a stout is in this one.  A very excellent example of the style.
Pitch black with a khaki head.  Deep roasted chocolate and roasted malts on the nose.  Very nice thickness with a good roasted malt flavor thats balanced by the chocolate quite well.

12oz from keg and barrel in plano.  Nice to see this since I didnt even know it existed.  Pours black with a nice stable small creamy tan head.  Nose is nicely malted with a touch of chocolate.  Taste is chewy, roasty and chocolaty, gotta say this is a pretty good, balanced foreign stout.

Bottle. Nose is inviting, tootsie roll, slight fruitiness, earthy tobacco and lightly roasted coffee. Initial flavor is the tootsie rolls (brown sugar and dark chocolate) with a nice cookie dough malt thing going. Carbonation is prickly - maybe a little much. Finish is first a nice bitter roasted cocoa bean that turns a little chemical and leaves some slickness. Alcohol is noticeable in the finish. Drinkable and decent, a bit of a letdown.

Eclipsed chestnut. Dying uneven ring of light-tan bubbles. Ashy, brown sugary nose with scents of scorched malt hulls, burnt cookies, cocoa, charcoal, cola, molasses and prune juice. Soft prickles of carbonation deposit a fuzzy residue on the palate. Harshly roasty and pungent with crunchy char reminiscent of burnt cookies. Suggestive notes of tarry java and smoke. Stiff black malt bite lends considerable acidity as well as some unpleasant phenols. Acidic and astringent, throughout, with very little texture, depth or softness to the grain. Underattenuated, limp and sugary, as well, with sloppy overstated notes of molasses and cola. No discernable malt softness or pale malt nuance to negate the sugariness. Closes acridly with an off-putting mixture of cola reduction, molasses and charred malt. Lots of conspicuous flaws here, namely the poorly cloaked alcohol, limpness of body, prickly carbonation, acridness, stark and unrefined malt character, etc. Down the drain.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: 12oz bottle. Black pour with a big light brown head. Sweet and creamy malt nose with chocolate and roasty. Roasty flavor with creamy chocolate, a hint of alcohol, and a roasty sweet finish. Was hoping a bit of the sweetness would fade as it warmed, but it actually became more intense. Still a good brew though.
Pours dark black with reddish hues and mostly receding tan head. Notes of toffee, brown sugar, fruity esters, rye bread, spicy phenols. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Dark black, hints of brown and red around the edges, short cocoa brown head.  Aroma is coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is sweet and thinner up front with a robust coffee/chocolate bitter finish and lingering licorice.  This is  a really delicious cold weather brew.  Rich without overwhelming the palate, you can easily drink a few of these in a session.

Burnt cacao nibs, fresh coffee, tobacco, and blackstrap molasses nose.  Jet black color, large foamy tab head with nice lacing.  Deep rich sweetness with a long determined, but not offensive, bitter bite for solid balace.  Medium carbonation, big body/mouth feel, finish is roasted malts with long warm burn.  Really well done Stout, big on deep roasted malt flavors, but not some of the heavy bitterness from the dark malts.  All around a very elegant beer.

Pours a very dark brown, nearly black, with a moderately full, light tan, creamy head which is mostly lasting and does leave nice, tight, frothy lace.  Nose is nice with some dark chocolates, moderate roast, light burnt toast, hints of smoke, light notes of roasted walnut, and some light earthy/floral hops in the background.  The flavor is similar with similar hop notes being more prominent; bakers chocolate, roasted walnuts, hints of leather, moderate hop presence, and burnt toast.  The bitterness is moderately high both from the hops and the roasted notes.  Palate is moderately full, creamy, velvety, soft to lively, and just lightly drying.  Finishes fairly long and mostly bitter with strong roasts, burnt toast, and earthy/floral hops lingering.  From a style which I tend not to like, this one was quite nice.  Interesting addition of the "kick-you-in-the-ass" hops which was nice and balancing but still assertive.  The dryness was minimal and there were no chalky, ashy notes usually associated with foreign stouts.  Overall, a nice beer from an average brewery.

Dark red-brown pour with a lightbrown head. Aroma of lactose, coffee, roasted malt. Taste is roasted malt, coffee, sweetness with a roasted malt, creamy sweet aftertaste. This was a great beer to have on my last Sat. outdoor fire for this year. It is getting cold (43 tonight). Nice flavors, very tasty beer. Nice lacing. The head lasted until the last swallow.

12 oz bottle and served in my Bells snifter: Deep brown and nearly opaque with a small fading tan frothy head that did leave sheets o lace upon the glassware. The aroma has notes of lush chocolate, walnut, toffee and charred malt along with a hit of coffee, prune, anise, grassy and herbal hop, leathery and a bit of tobacco too. The taste is sweet and earthy malts, light smoky notes supported by twangy fruit and liquorice before a finish of coffee and herbal hops. The mouth feel is medium-bodied and a touch oily. Overall I can say this is a nice surprise. Well not world-class newsworthy it is a darn solid stout with character. I will very much enjoy the rest of the sixer, get ya some Stouties.

12oz. bottle. Somewhat disappointed with this. Aroma is dirty smelling. Reminds of mud or peat. Strong bitter coffee flavor. A little thin and head disappears almost immediately. Drinkable, I guess. Left Hand has done alot better.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a mocha head of short duration, with a bit of lacing, over a clear, black (SRM 40) body.....nose is heavy coffee, lighter chocolate, toffee, smoke, soy sauce, mild hop spice.....taste is coffee, toffee, bit of cocoa, finishing with a lingering coffee-hop bitterness.....mouth feel is thick and creamy, carbonation is medium. For my palate this is a bit unbalanced toward the coffee flavors in the dark roasted malts, but over all this is a rich thick creation.

12 ounce bottle - its nice to see them putting this in sixers rather than bombers - anyway, pours a dark brown, nearly black, with a light tan head - nose of bitter chocolate, coffee, chocolate chip cookies, some toasty character - fairly creamy mouthfeel, medium to full bodied - medium sweet, with a roast and black malt and hop bitterness to balance that quality - notes of tobacco, bittersweet chocolate, a touch of smoke - some alcohol heat in the finish - one of the better beers Ive had from this brewer in quite some time.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2010 12oz bottled on 11/04/09.  Pours dark brown, black in the glass, with a small tan head.  First bottle had very little head and lacing, second bottle is retaining more head and leaving lots of sticky lacing on the glass (albeit a different glass this time).  Good roasted aroma along with some coffee, bakers chocolate, and licorice.  Excellent flavor, lots of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, some dark fruits.  Lasting finish.  Despite the body being on the thin side, the mouthfeel is surprisingly full and smooth although a bit more carbonation than I usually like.  Overall a very impressive brew.

bottle.  pours a decent black with a nice small tan head.... aromas of coffee, licorice, and roasted sweet malts.  soft medium body with a touch of spice up front and bigger roasted malts down the sides.  there is a decent amount of sweetness throughout, while the coffee flavors bring it down a notch... nice bitter finish.  I look forward to next years offering.

12oz bottle.  almost black with ruby highlights under a small tan head.  chocolate chip cookies, toast, and milk chocolate aroma.  the palate is moderately creamy.  flavors of milk chocolate and toast with a a bit of bitterness.  moderately dry finish.  as far as foreign stouts go, this is pretty top notch.  lots of fresh baked, toasty chocolate chip cookies in the flavor.

Black pour with a nice tan head, good retention and lacing.  Aroma is made up of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and nuts.  Flavors of licorice, coffee, chocolate and dark fruit.  Decent duration on the palate.  Medium body, low carbonation and minimal alcohol warmth... 8% is well hidden!  A very quaffable stout, gotta be careful with this one!  Good one by Left Hand and very cool label by Moxie Sozo.

Bottle from Belmont in Dayton.  Dark color with lightly transparent edges.  Nice brown head.  Flavor is moderate coffee and sweetness.  Flavor is nice and well balanced.  Coffee, sweet malts, roasted flavors and hops come together well and are accompanied by a smooth creamy texture. Overall, nicely crafted stout.

12 oz. bottle from Macs on West Peachtree. Nice fluffy head that slowly fades away. Rather thin pour. Not completely opaque, but still rather dark. Nice pungent roast flavor, but not extremely nuanced. Slight sweet coffee as well. Nice sweet malt aroma as well. Very nice roast flavor I must say. Slight coffee flavor as well. Nice extremely smooth, but it has a decent palate. It has some great roast/coffee flavors, but still it is a bit thin. Very big roast flavor, and a slight bitterness. Overall, fairly decent brew.

At All Colorado beer Festival. Light black with thin head. Aroma is licorice, light coffee, but heavily malty with lighter use of hops, and molasses. Flavors are also licorice, which i must say stands out to me throughout the entirety of brew, caramel, coffee, and less notable hop presence that does add some more notable bite. Burnt lasting finish.

Had at the All Colorado Beer Festival in Colorado Springs on 11/7/09.  Color is black with a nice thick brown head.  Aroma is a deep dry roasted malt scent.  Starting with a bold medium body it goes down easy with a creamy feel.  Finish is a deeply roasted giving coffee, chocolate and nut flavors.  After taste is dry with the roasted flavor hanging on.  Overall its a very good stout that is very easy to drink with a light feel.

Bottle.  Pours black with an average, creamy dark brown head, mostly lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, chocolate, coffee, toffee, nutty), average hop (herbs), average yeast (leather) with notes of prune, wood, smoke, and licorice.  Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Long duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.
